revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork/wikidata|year=after 1670s|artist=}} '''''A Lady Playing the Guitar''''' (after 1670s) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by an unknown copyist after a work by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] painter [[Johannes Vermeer]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is part of the collection of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. [[File:Jan Vermeer van Delft 013.jpg|thumb|''[[The Guitar Player (Vermeer)|The Guitar Player]]'', original in [[Kenwood House]]]] This painting by a follower of Vermeer was documented as authentic by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1908, who wrote; "26. A LADY PLAYING THE GUITAR. [[Théophile Thoré-Bürger|B.]] 28. [[Henry Havard|H.]] 31.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn01hofsuoft#page/606/mode/1up Comparative table] of catalog entries between Bürger's and Havard's first [[Catalogue raisonné]] of Vermeer and Hofstede de Groot's list of Vermeer paintings in 1908</ref> A young lady with fresh red cheeks, wearing a white silk dress and a yellow jacket trimmed with ermine, sits on the left facing the spectator. Her figure is seen at three-quarter length. She looks with a smile at something above her to the left. Behind her is a table with a blue cloth, on which are several books. On the wall hangs a landscape. The scene is lighted from a window with a dark blue curtain on the right. The colours are delicately harmonised. The paint is thin. This picture belongs to about the same period as the [[Lady Standing at a Virginal|National Gallery picture (23)]]. Signed in full ; canvas, 19 1/2 inches by 16 1/2 inches. Exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] Winter Exhibition, 1892, No. 46. The picture was, after Vermeer's death in 1676, in the possession of his widow, Catharina Bolnes ; this picture, and "[[Lady Writing a Letter with her Maid|The Love Letter]]" in the Beit collection (35), were given as security for a debt of 617 florins. Sales. Amsterdam, May 16, 1696, No. 4 (70 florins). Ph. van der Schley and D. du Pre, Amsterdam, December 22, 1817, No. 62 (65 florins 5, Coclers). In the possession of the dealer Gruyter, Amsterdam. In the collections of J. H. C. Cremer, Brussels measuring, according to Bürger, 21 inches by 18 inches; of Lord Iveagh ; of Henry Bischoffsheim, London. In the possession of the dealer Gooden, London, 1896. Now in the collection of [[John G. Johnson]], Philadelphia."<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn01hofsuoft#page/593/mode/1up entry 26 for A Lady Playing the Guitar] in Hofstede de Groot, 1908 {{PD-notice}}</ref>
Years later it became apparent that Hofstede de Groot (and Johnson G. Johnson) had been tricked and this was a copy of the version in Kenwood House. It is thanks to Johnson's deeply founded interest in art that all dubious attributions of paintings in his possession such as this one were allowed to remain in the collection, where it has become a quiet testament to the "Vermeer craze" at the turn of the 20th-century. Even after seeing the Kenwood House version, Hofstede de Groot was convinced of this painting's superiority, which demonstrates the skill of the unknown copyist. Needless to say the provenance records mentioned by Hofstede de Groot pertain to the Kenwood House version. It is still unknown where the dealer "Gooden" acquired the painting. == References == {{reflist}} * [http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/102282.html Lady Playing the Guitar] on museum website (not on show)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lady Playing the Guitar}} [[Category:1680s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Philadelphia Museum of Art]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]]
{{17C-painting-stub}}

{{Expand Italian|Ragazza afgana|date=February 2017}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox person |name = Afghan Girl |image = Sharbat Gula.jpg |image_upright = |caption = 1984 photographic portrait by journalist [[Steve McCurry]] |native_name = شربت ګله Sharbat Gula |native_name_lang = ps |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Nangarhar]], [[Afghanistan]] |residence = [[Kabul]], Afghanistan |nationality = [[Afghan people|Afghan]] |occupation = [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]], [[BBC Pashto]] |parents = |website = |known for = Being the subject of the cover photo of the June 1985 issue of ''National Geographic'' magazine }} [[File:Sharbat Gula - Brussels - 2017.jpg|thumb|300px|The World of [[Steve McCurry]] exposition in Palais de la Bourse of Brussels in May 2017]] '''''Afghan Girl''''' is a 1984 photographic portrait of '''Sharbat Gula''' ({{lang-ps|شربت ګله}}) (pronounced {{IPA-ps|ˈʃaɾbat|}}) (born {{circa|1972}}), also known as '''Sharbat Bibi''', by journalist [[Steve McCurry]].<ref name="Dawn">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1165626/pakistan-issues-cnic-to-nat-geos-famed-afghan-girl|title=Pakistan issues CNIC to Nat Geo's famed 'Afghan Girl'|last=Ismail Khan|date=February 25, 2015|work=[[DAWN (newspaper)|DAWN]]|accessdate=7 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150628132319/http://www.dawn.com/news/1165626/pakistan-issues-cnic-to-nat-geos-famed-afghan-girl|archivedate=28 June 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> It appeared on the June 1985 cover of ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]''. The image is of an adolescent girl with green eyes in a red headscarf looking intensely at the camera. The identity of the photo's subject was not initially known, but in early 2002, she was identified as Sharbat Gula. She was an [[Afghan]] woman who was living in the [[Nasir Bagh]] [[Afghans in Pakistan|refugee camp in Pakistan]] during the time of the [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet occupation of Afghanistan]] when she was photographed.
It has been likened to [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s painting of the ''[[Mona Lisa]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2002/03/12/afghan-girl.htm|title=National Geographic tracks down Afghan girl|last=Zoroya|first=Greg|date=2002-03-13|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=2012-02-14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228174224/http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2002/03/12/afghan-girl.htm|archivedate=2012-02-28|deadurl=no|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meridian.org/insmallthingsremembered/hollywood-movie-poster-at-the-kabul-cinema|title=Hollywood movie poster at the Kabul Cinema|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121222043007/http://www.meridian.org/insmallthingsremembered/hollywood-movie-poster-at-the-kabul-cinema|archivedate=2012-12-22|deadurl=no|accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref> and has been called "the First World's Third World ''Mona Lisa''".<ref>{{cite book|title=Just Advocacy?: Women's Human Rights, Transnational Feminisms, and the Politics of Representation|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2005|isbn=9780813535890|editor=Wendy S. Hesford|page=1|editor2=Wendy Kozol}}</ref> The image became "emblematic" of "refugee girl/woman located in some distant camp" deserving of the compassion of the Western viewer.<ref name="CainHowe2008">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_rbBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA87|title=Women, Crime and Social Harm: Towards a Criminology for the Global Age|last1=Cain|first1=Maureen|last2=Howe|first2=Adrian|date=2008-11-03|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781847314703|pages=87–|accessdate=7 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220184835/https://books.google.com/books?id=t_rbBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA87|archivedate=20 February 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==''National Geographic ''== Gula was one of the students in an informal school in the [[Nasir Bagh]] [[refugee camp]] in 1984. Gula's photograph was taken by [[National Geographic Society]] photographer Steve McCurry on [[Kodachrome]] 64 color slide film, with a [[Nikon]] [[Nikon FM2|FM2]] camera and [[Nikon]] 105mm Ai-S F2.5 lens.<ref> {{cite journal |year=1988 |title=Portfolio |journal=Nikon World |edition=Summer |volume=4 |issue=1 |page=9 |publisher=[[Nikon]] |oclc=2265134 |accessdate=2012-01-14 |url=http://www.gloryman.com.tw/prod_pic_show.php?id=4888&pic=0 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CUueh4q2?url=http://www.gloryman.com.tw/prod_pic_show.php?id=4888&pic=0 |archivedate=2012-11-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The pre-print photo retouching was done by Graphic Art Service, based in [[Marietta, Georgia]]. McCurry did not record the name of the person he had photographed.
The picture, titled ''Afghan Girl'', appeared on the June 1985 cover of ''National Geographic''. The image of her face, with a red scarf draped loosely over her head and her eyes staring directly into the camera was named "the most recognized photograph" in the history of the magazine, and the cover itself is one of the most famous of the ''National Geographic''.<ref> {{cite news |title=National Geographic: Afghan Girl, A Life Revealed |last=McCurry |first=Steve |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/liveonline/02/world/world_mccurry041002.htm |work=[[The Washington Post]] |publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]] |oclc=56914684 |date=10 April 2001 |accessdate=2012-01-14 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CUuA3KLQ?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/liveonline/02/world/world_mccurry041002.htm |archivedate=27 November 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''American Photo'' magazine says the image has an "unusual combination of grittiness and glamour".<ref>{{cite journal|journal=American Photo |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yunn27aRiF0C&pg=PA45 |volume=XIII |number=4 |date=July–August 2002 |title=Photographer of the Year: Steve McCurry |pages=43–54: 45 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220235838/https://books.google.com/books?id=Yunn27aRiF0C&pg=PA45 |archivedate=2017-02-20 }}</ref> Her green eyes are the subject of frequent commentary.<ref name="CainHowe2008"/><ref name="Geographic2010">{{cite book|last=Geographic |first=National |title=In Focus: National Geographic Greatest Portraits |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NlX70a1DfHwC&pg=PA355 |accessdate=7 September 2015 |date=2010-09-15 |publisher=National Geographic Society |isbn=9781426206474 |pages=355– |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220115910/https://books.google.com/books?id=NlX70a1DfHwC&pg=PA355 |archivedate=20 February 2017 }}</ref><ref name="RathgebUhl2012">{{cite book|last1=Rathgeb |first1=Christian |last2=Uhl |first2=Andreas |last3=Wild |first3=Peter |title=Iris Biometrics: From Segmentation to Template Security |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JVxDAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA3 |accessdate=7 September 2015 |date=2012-11-08 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=9781461455714 |pages=3– |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220110819/https://books.google.com/books?id=JVxDAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA3 |archivedate=20 February 2017 }}</ref>
McCurry made several unsuccessful attempts during the 1990s to locate her.<ref name="HesfordKozol2005">{{cite book|last1=Hesford |first1=Wendy S. |last2=Kozol |first2=Wendy |title=Just Advocacy?: Women's Human Rights, Transnational Feminisms, and the Politics of Representation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7G5SPSay_dEC&pg=PA1 |accessdate=7 September 2015 |year=2005 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |isbn=9780813535890 |pages=1– |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220212900/https://books.google.com/books?id=7G5SPSay_dEC&pg=PA1 |archivedate=20 February 2017 }}</ref> In January 2002, a ''National Geographic'' team traveled to Afghanistan to locate the subject. McCurry, upon learning that the Nasir Bagh refugee camp was soon to close, inquired of its remaining residents, one of whom knew Gula's brother and was able to send word to her hometown. However, a number of women came forward and identified themselves erroneously as the famous Afghan Girl. In addition, after being shown the 1984 photo, a handful of young men erroneously identified Gula as their wife.
The team located Gula, then around the age of 30, in a remote region of Afghanistan; she had returned to her native country from the refugee camp in 1992. Her identity was confirmed by [[John Daugman]] using [[iris recognition]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~jgd1000/afghan.html |title=How the Afghan Girl was Identified by Her Iris Patterns |last=Daugman |first=John |accessdate=2012-01-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112033216/http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~jgd1000/afghan.html |archivedate=2012-01-12 }}</ref> She recalled being photographed. She had been photographed on only three occasions: in 1984 and during the search for her when a ''National Geographic'' producer took the identifying pictures that led to the reunion with Steve McCurry. She had never seen the ''Afghan Girl'' image before it was shown to her in January 2002.
==Sharbat Gula== [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] by ethnicity and from a [[rural]] background, Gula's parents were killed during the [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Soviet–Afghan War|bombing of Afghanistan]] when she was around six years old in their village in eastern [[Nangarhar Province|Nangarhar]]. Along with her grandmother, brother, and three sisters, she walked across the mountains to Pakistan and ended up in the Nasir Bagh refugee camp in Pakistan in 1984.<ref name=ng>{{cite journal|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2002/04/afghan-girl/index-text |title=Afghan Girl: A Life Revealed |last=Newman |first=Cathy |work=[[National Geographic Magazine]] |date=April 2002 |accessdate=2012-01-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113085238/http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2002/04/afghan-girl/index-text |archivedate=2012-01-13}}</ref>
She married Rahmat Gul between the age of 13 and 16, and returned to her village in Afghanistan in 1992. She is now a widow as her husband died from [[Hepatitis C virus]] around 2012.<ref name="abc-deport" /> Gula has three daughters. A fourth daughter died in infancy. She expressed hopes that her children will be able to get an education. A devout Muslim, Gula normally would wear a burka and was hesitant to meet with McCurry, as he was a male from outside the family. When asked if she had ever felt safe, she responded "No. But life under the Taliban was better. At least there was peace and order." Until the ''National Geographic'' team found her again, she had never seen the photo of herself as a child. When asked how she had survived, she responded that it was "the will of God".<ref name=ng />
In 2015, local newspapers in Pakistan reported that the [[National Database and Registration Authority]] (NADRA) canceled the Computerized National Identity Card (CNIC) to Sharbat Bibi and two men listed as her sons. Reports claimed the national ID cards had been issued illegally. A NADRA source is quoted as saying "They may not be her sons but this is a common practice among Afghan refugees whereby they list names of non-relatives as their children to obtain documents." A relative stated that the family lives in Pakistan, but "We travel between Pakistan and Afghanistan depending on the security situation."<ref name="Dawn" />
On 26 October 2016, Gula was arrested in Pakistan by the [[Federal Investigation Agency]] for living in the country using forged documents.<ref name=Express_Tribune>{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/1210753/fia-arrests-natgeos-afghan-girl-peshawar/ |title=FIA arrests NatGeo's Afghan girl in Peshawar |newspaper=The Express Tribune |date=26 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026232441/http://tribune.com.pk/story/1210753/fia-arrests-natgeos-afghan-girl-peshawar/ |archivedate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/26/national-geographic-afghan-girl-arrested-pakistan-false-papers-sharbat-gula |title=National Geographic 'Afghan Girl' arrested in Pakistan living under false papers |last=Boone |first=Jon |date=2016-10-26 |newspaper=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077 |access-date=2016-10-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026234650/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/26/national-geographic-afghan-girl-arrested-pakistan-false-papers-sharbat-gula |archivedate=2016-10-26}}</ref> She was sentenced to fifteen days in detention, and she was deported to Afghanistan.<ref name="abc-deport" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2016/11/09/pakistan-deports-national-geographics-iconic-afghan-girl|title=Pakistan deports National Geographic's iconic 'Afghan Girl' |publisher=[[Toronto Sun]]|author=Lynne O'Donnell and Riaz Khan|date=November 9, 2016|accessdate=2016-11-13}}</ref> The decision was criticised by [[Amnesty International]].<ref name="abc-deport">{{cite news|title=Pakistan to deport National Geographic's 'Afghan Girl' Sharbat Gula next week |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-05/pakistan-to-deport-national-geographic-afghan-girl-sharbat-gula/7997680 |accessdate=5 November 2016 |publisher=ABC News |agency=AP |date=5 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105133327/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-05/pakistan-to-deport-national-geographic-afghan-girl-sharbat-gula/7997680 |archivedate=5 November 2016}}</ref> In [[Kabul]], Gula and her children were welcomed by President [[Ashraf Ghani]] and former President [[Hamid Karzai]] at the [[Arg (Kabul)|presidential palace]]. The government promised to support her financially.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-38640487|title=‘Green-eyed girl’ in quest for new life|first=Dawood |last=Azami|date=17 March 2018|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> In December 2017, Gula was gifted a {{convert|3000|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} residence in Kabul for her and her children to live in.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/12/afghan-girl-home-afghanistan/|title=Famed 'Afghan Girl' Finally Gets a Home|date=12 December 2017|work=National Geographic}}</ref>
==Legacy== Interest in the photo increased after [[9/11 attacks]] when the George W. Bush administration began using women's rights to help promote support for the war in Afghanistan.<ref name="HesfordKozol2005"/><ref name="Whitlock2010">{{cite book|last=Whitlock |first=Gillian |title=Soft Weapons: Autobiography in Transit |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4C09Yao332gC&pg=PA71 |accessdate=7 September 2015 |date=2010-02-15 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=9780226895277 |pages=71– |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220110815/https://books.google.com/books?id=4C09Yao332gC&pg=PA71 |archivedate=20 February 2017 }}</ref>
More recent pictures of Gula were featured as part of a cover story on her life in the April 2002 issue of ''National Geographic'' and she was the subject of a [[television documentary]], entitled ''Search for the Afghan Girl'', which aired in March 2002. In recognition of her,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.co.uk/news/2002/03/0311_020312_sharbat_2.html |title=How They Found National Geographic's 'Afghan Girl' |last=Braun |first=David |work=National Geographic News |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |date=7 March 2003 |accessdate=2012-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112131951/http://news.nationalgeographic.co.uk/news/2002/03/0311_020312_sharbat_2.html |archivedate=12 January 2012 |df= }}</ref> ''National Geographic'' set up the Afghan Girls Fund, a charitable organization with the goal of educating Afghan girls and young women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/donate/afghan_girls_fund.html|title=National Geographic Society: Afghan Girls Fund|accessdate=2009-03-15|date=August 2004|publisher=[[National Geographic Society]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041206042103/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/donate/afghan_girls_fund.html|archivedate=2004-12-06}}</ref> In 2008, the scope of the fund was broadened to include boys and the name was changed to Afghan Children's Fund.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/donate/afghan-childrens-fund.html |title=National Geographic Society: Afghan Children's Fund |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |accessdate=2012-01-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111224051448/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/donate/afghan-childrens-fund.html |archivedate=2011-12-24 }}</ref> After finding Gula, ''National Geographic'' also covered the costs of medical treatment for her family, and paid for the costs of a [[Hajj|pilgrimage to Mecca]].<ref>{{cite news|title='Afghan girl' cameraman tells stories behind pictures |journal=The Bosnia Times |url=http://www.thebosniatimes.com/en/afghan-girl-cameraman-tells-stories-behind-pictures/ |date=October 30, 2013 |accessdate=July 26, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140423165548/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thebosniatimes.com%2Fen%2Fafghan-girl-cameraman-tells-stories-behind-pictures%2F |archivedate=April 23, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book|first=Steve|last=McCurry|title=Untold: The Stories Behind the Photographs|publisher=Phaidon Press|year=2013|isbn=978-0714864624}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Sharbat Gula}} * [http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2002/04/afghan-girl/index-text "A Life Revealed"]—[[National Geographic Magazine|''National Geographic'']] * {{IMDb title|id=0406199|title=Search for the Afghan Girl}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090814100937/http://photography.nationalgeographic.com/photography/enlarge/afghan-girl-before-after_pod_image.html "Before and After - The ''Afghan Girl'' (1984 and 2002)"]—[[National Geographic Magazine|''National Geographic'']] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BIgx-nkFL6c "'Afghan Girl': Taking ''National Geographic''{{'}}s Most Famous Photo"], [[FORA.tv]], [[Chautauqua Institution|The Chautauqua Institution]], [[YouTube]], July 29, 2010 (video clip). * {{cite news |last=Hajek |first=Daniel |date=July 26, 2015 |title=How One Photographer Captured a Piercing Gaze That Shook the World |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/07/26/425659961/how-one-photographer-captured-a-piercing-gaze-that-shook-the-world |newspaper=[[All Things Considered]] |publisher=[[NPR]] |department=My Big Break (story series) |access-date=July 27, 2015}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Ajoka Theatre | logo = ajoka.png | caption = The logo of Ajoka Theatre | trading_name = | native_name = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1984|05|14|df=y}} | founder = [[Madeeha Gauhar]] | type = [[Not-for-profit arts organization]] | industry = Entertainment | genre = Urdu and Punjabi plays, social performance, street theatre & theatre for peace | location_city = [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] | location_country = [[Pakistan]] | locations = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Madeeha Gauahar
[[Shahid Nadeem]] | homepage = {{URL|http://ajoka.org.pk/}} | intl = }} '''Ajoka Theatre''' ([[Urdu]]: {{Nastaliq|اجوکا ناٹک}}, literal translation of ''Ajoka'': "today/present") is a [[Pakistan]]i [[not-for-profit arts organization]] based in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], with focus on producing and performing social theatrical stage productions, founded in 1984.Singh Bajeli, Diwan (2 February 2007) [http://www.hindu.com/fr/2007/02/02/stories/2007020201230300.htm ''A voice for peace and amity''], The Hindu The group was formed by director, actress and playwright, [[Madeeha Gauhar]] at peak of the tensions during the state of emergency under the regime of General [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq]]. Ajoka Theatre received the prestigious [[Prince Claus Awards|Prince Claus Award]](16 December 2003) [http://www.dawn.com/news/223580/madeeha-gauhar-gets-dutch-award ''Madeeha Gauhar gets Dutch awards''], Dawn NewsPrince Claus Awards, [http://princeclausfund.org/en/programmes/awards award winners of 2006] in 2006 and the [[Theatre Pasta Theatre Awards|International Theatre Pasta Award]] in 2007.Theatre Pasta (16 July 2008) [http://theatrepasta.com/?p=81 interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219114602/http://theatrepasta.com/?p=81 |date=19 February 2012 }} Since its inception, the group have staged many popular society critical pieces in theatres, on the streets and in public spaces, as well as in productions for television and on video. Ajoka Theatre has not only performed in Pakistan, but has also in the [[South Asia]]n region, in countries like [[India]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Nepal]] and [[Sri Lanka]], as well as in [[Europe]] and [[United States of America]].Prince Claus Fund, [http://princeclausfund.org/en/network/user/id/241 profile]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The group focuses on promotion of a [[justice|just]], [[Humanism|humane]], [[Secularity|secular]] and [[Egalitarianism|equal]] society, alongside the subject of [[women's rights]] in a society that is greatly dominated by men. The groups first ever theatrical performance was ''Jaloos (Procession)'' written by veteran Indian playwright [[Badal Sarkar]].Khan, Sher (14 May 2014) [http://tribune.com.pk/story/708368/30-years-of-ajoka/ ''30 years of Ajoka''], The Express Tribune The style of Ajoka's performances can be characterised as an elaboration on the [[oral tradition]] of [[Bhand]] and [[Nautanki]] that found a flourishing base in the area that currently overlaps the province of [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]]. In spite of the Western education of Gauhar, she does not limit herself to classical Western theatre techniques. Instead, she mixes authentic Pakistani elements, combining it with contemporary sentiments. ==History== Gauhar was born in 1956 in [[Karachi]]. After she obtained a [[Master of Arts]] degree in [[English literature]], she moved to [[England]] where she obtained another master's degree, in [[theatre]] sciences at the [[University of London]].Rashed, Fariha (16 October 2005) [https://archive.is/20130408022347/http://archives.dawn.com/weekly/images/archive/051016/images1.htm ''The Ajoka awakening''] In 1983, after returning to [[Lahore]], Gauhar and her husband [[Shahid Nadeem]] founded Ajoka Theatre, the first theatre group of significance there. In 2007, Ajoka performed a piece that was written and directed by Gauhar, called ''[[Burqavaganza]]'' (''[[Burqa]]-vaganza''), which led to great controversy. Actors dressed in burkas put themes on the stage like sexual discrimination, intolerance and fanaticism. From a Western perspective, the piece was a rather innocent performance on hypocrisy of a society that bathes in corruption. In her own country though, Members of Parliament called for a ban of it, and the Minister of Culture threatened with sanctions when it would be staged any longer. In spite of the ban, [[non-governmental organisation]]s and [[women's rights]] activists had the theatre piece translated into English and staged performances internationally as an sign of support to Ajoka.Rehman, Sonya (20 June 2008) [http://sonyarehman.wordpress.com/2008/06/20/viva-ajoka/ ''Viva Ajoka!''], Sonya Rehman's Archive ~ Of Most Things PakistaniBorah, Prabalika M. (4 May 2011) [http://www.hindu.com/mp/2011/03/04/stories/2011030450360500.htm ''Voice beyond LOC''], The Hindu On 23 August 2008, [[Alhamra Arts Council]] hosted the launch of ''Selected Plays'' published by [[Oxford University Press]] (OUP) and written by [[Shahid Nadeem]] with the help of Ajoka.{{cite journal|author=Tim Kindseth|title=Cold Plays|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=23 October 2008|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1853122,00.html|accessdate=15 April 2013}} The book contains seven of his famous plays ''Teesri Dastak'', ''Barri'', ''Aik Thi Nani'', ''Kala Meda Bhes'', ''Dukhini'', ''Bulha'' and ''[[Burqavaganza]]''.{{cite news|title=Alhamra hosts launch of Nadeem's 'Selected Plays'|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2008%5C08%5C24%5Cstory_24-8-2008_pg13_5|accessdate=14 April 2013|newspaper=[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]]|date=24 August 2008}} The book again launched at the [[Pakistan National Council of the Arts]] (PNCA), [[Islamabad]] on 25 August 2008 with the help of [[Pakistan Academy of Letters]].{{cite news|title=Ajoka Theatre launches book of selected plays|url=http://archives.dawn.com/2008/08/26/nat8.htm|accessdate=14 April 2013|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=26 August 2008}} His book, ''Selected Plays'', a collection of his six famous plays in an English translation was published by OUP in August 2008.{{cite web|title=Selected Plays: Shahid Nadeem|url=http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780195474770.do|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|accessdate=3 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140810042849/http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780195474770.do|archive-date=10 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Two collections of his Urdu and Punjabi plays has been published.{{cite book|title=The Columbia encyclopedia of modern drama|year=2007|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|location=United States|page=947|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=aQqOKWmjdQUC&pg=PA947&lpg=PA947&dq=Shahid+Nadeem+wife&source=bl&ots=dz2tUvB6zx&sig=ZTHyzeNlnYq9dshTy565JMjB6Gg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YJtrUfKLIZHQrQeT9oGYDQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Shahid%20Nadeem%20wife&f=false}} In 2012, Nadeem wrote a play ''Kaun Hai Yeh Gustakh'',{{cite news|title=Saadat Hassan vs Manto: Bringing Manto to the stage|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/480305/saadat-hassan-vs-manto-bringing-manto-to-the-stage/|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=The Express Tribune|date=16 December 2012}} directed by [[Madeeha Gauhar]] and first played at [[Alhamra Arts Council]], Lahore on 14 December by Ajoka. The play is based on the life of Saadat Hassan Manto, and was well received by audiences. Manto was played by ''Naseem Abbas''.{{cite news|title=Kaun Hai Yeh Gustakh: the best understanding of Manto|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-5-162761-Kaun-Hai-Yeh-Gustakh-the-best-understanding-of-Manto|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=The News|date=1 March 2013}} In January 2013 the play was presented at the ''Akshara Theatre'' in New Delhi, India.{{cite news|title=Pakistani group stages play despite cancellation by NSD|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/pakistani-group-stages-play-despite-cancellation-by-nsd/article4323881.ece|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=20 January 2013}} The play was due to be presented at the [[National School of Drama]] (NSD) in New Delhi but was cancelled due to security concerns.{{cite news|title=Another casualty: 2 Pakistani plays cancelled|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/another-casualty-2-pakistani-plays-cancelled/article4317008.ece|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=18 January 2013}} In February 2013, play was held at [[Nishtar Hall]], [[Peshawar]] by Ajoka.{{cite news|title=Paying homage: Remembering the controversy that was Manto|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/508758/paying-homage-remembering-the-controversy-that-was-manto/|accessdate=13 April 2013|newspaper=The Express Tribune|date=18 February 2013}} ==Productions== Ajoka Theatre has staged several theatrical performances, mostly all plays have been adapted or written by [[Madeeha Gauhar]] and [[Shahid Nadeem]]. {{colbegin|colwidth=33em}} * 1984: ''Jaloos'', by [[Badal Sarkar]] * 1985: ''[[The Caucasian Chalk Circle|Chalk Chakkar]]'', by [[Bertolt Brecht]] * 1987: ''Barri'', by [[Shahid Nadeem]] * 1987: ''Marya Hoya Kutta'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1988: ''Itt'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1989: ''Choolah'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1990: ''Jhali Kithay Jaway'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1991: ''Teesri Dastak'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1992: ''Lappar'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1992: ''[[Toba Tek Singh (short story)|Toba Tek Singh]]'', by [[Saadat Hassan Manto]] * 1992: ''Dekh Tamasha Chaltha Ban'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1993: ''Aik Thee Naani'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1994: ''Kali Ghata: Acting for Nature'' by [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF Pakistan]] * 1995: ''Jum Jum Jeevay Jaman Pura'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1996: ''Kala Mainda Bhes'', by [[Madeeha Gauhar]] * 1997: ''Dukhini'', by Shahid Nadeem * 1998: ''[[The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui|Bala King]]'', by Bertolt Brecht * 2000: ''Adhoori'', by [[Kishwar Naheed]], [[Fehmida Riaz]] and [[Ishrat Afreen]] * 2001: ''Chal Melay Nu Chaliay'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2001: ''[[Bulleh Shah|Bullah]]'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2004: ''Mainoon Kari Kareenday Ni Mae'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2004: ''Piro Preman'', by Dr. Swarajbir * 2004: ''Shehr-e-Afsos'', by [[Intezar Hussain]] * 2005: ''Border, Border'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2006: ''Dukh Darya'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2006: ''Dushman'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2006: ''Maon Kay Naam'', by Saadat Hasan Manto * 2007: ''Surkh Gulaaba'n Da Mausam'', by [[Mazhar Tirmazi]] * 2007: ''[[Burqavaganza]]'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2008: ''Hotel Mohenjodaro'', by [[Ghulam Abbas (writer)|Ghulam Abbas]] * 2009: ''Raja Rasalu'', by Malik Aslam * 2010: ''[[Dara Shikoh|Dara]]'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2011: ''The Dreams Can Come True'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2011: ''Mera Rang De Basanti Chola'', by Madeeha Gauhar * 2011: ''Amrika Chalo'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2012: ''Rozan-E-Zindan Se'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2012: ''Kaun Hai Yeh Gustakh'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2014: ''Lo Phir Basant Ayee'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2015: ''Kaun Bane Ga Badshah'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2016: ''[[Bhagat Kabir|Kabeera Khara Bazar Mai]]'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2016: ''Anhi Mai Da Sufna'', by Shahid Nadeem * 2016: ''Talismati Tota'', by Nirvaan Nadeem {{colend}} == References == {{reflist|3}} ==Bibliography== ===Literature=== *{{cite book |last=Afzal-Khan |first=Fawzia |title=A Critical Stage: The Role of Secular Alternative Theatre in Pakistan|publisher=[[Seagull Books]] |location=India |year=2005 |isbn=9788170462750}} *{{cite book |last=Nadeem |first=Shahid |title=Selected Plays |publisher=[[Oxford revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork|image=Christophe_Colomb_devant_le_conseil_de_Salamanque_-_Emanuel_Leutze_-_MBA_Lyon_2014.jpg|title=Christopher Columbus Before the Council of Salamanca|year=1841|artist=Emanuel Leutze|museum=Louvre}} '''''Christopher Columbus Before the Council of Salamanca''''' is an 1841 painting by the German-American artist [[Emanuel Leutze]], now in the [[Louvre]] in Paris. It was lent to the [[Musée des beaux-arts de Lyon]] in 2014 for its exhibition ''L'invention du Passé. Histoires de cœur et d'épée 1802-1850.''.
{{19C-painting-stub}} [[category:1841 paintings]] [[category:Paintings of the Louvre by American and British artists]] [[category:History paintings]] [[category:Cultural depictions of Christopher Columbus]]

Order 120 |- |colspan=6|Coxeter notation expresses [[Coxeter group]]s as a list of branch orders of a [[Coxeter diagram]], like the [[polyhedral groups]], {{CDD|node|p|node|q|node}} = [p,q]. [[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|dihedral groups]], {{CDD|node|2|node|n|node}}, can be expressed a product [ ]×[n] or in a single symbol with an explicit order 2 branch, [2,n]. |} In [[geometry]], '''Coxeter notation''' (also '''Coxeter symbol''') is a system of classifying [[symmetry group]]s, describing the angles between fundamental reflections of a [[Coxeter group]] in a bracketed notation expressing the structure of a [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]], with modifiers to indicate certain subgroups. The notation is named after [[H. S. M. Coxeter]], and has been more comprehensively defined by [[Norman Johnson (mathematician)|Norman Johnson]]. == Reflectional groups== {{Further information|Point group}} For [[Coxeter group]]s, defined by pure reflections, there is a direct correspondence between the bracket notation and [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]]. The numbers in the bracket notation represent the mirror reflection orders in the branches of the Coxeter diagram. It uses the same simplification, suppressing 2s between orthogonal mirrors. The Coxeter notation is simplified with exponents to represent the number of branches in a row for linear diagram. So the ''A''''n'' group is represented by [3''n''-1], to imply ''n'' nodes connected by ''n-1'' order-3 branches. Example ''A''2 = [3,3] = [32] or [31,1] represents diagrams {{CDD|node|3|node|3|node}} or {{CDD|node|split1|nodes}}. Coxeter initially represented bifurcating diagrams with vertical positioning of numbers, but later abbreviated with an exponent notation, like [...,3p,q] or [3p,q,r], starting with [31,1,1] or [3,31,1] = {{CDD|node|splitsplit1|branch3|node}} or {{CDD|node|3|node|split1|nodes}} as D4. Coxeter allowed for zeros as special cases to fit the ''A''''n'' family, like ''A''3 = [3,3,3,3] = [34,0,0] = [34,0] = [33,1] = [32,2], like {{CDD|node|3|node|3|node|3|node|3|node}} = {{CDD|node|split1|nodes|3a|nodea|3a|nodea}} = {{CDD|node|split1|nodes|3ab|nodes}}. Coxeter groups formed by cyclic diagrams are represented by parenthesese inside of brackets, like [(p,q,r)] = {{CDD|pqr}} for the [[triangle group]] (p q r). If the branch orders are equal, they can be grouped as an exponent as the length the cycle in brackets, like [(3,3,3,3)] = [3[4]], representing Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node|split1|nodes|split2|node}} or {{CDD|branch|3ab|branch}}. {{CDD|node|3|node|split1|branch}} can be represented as [3,(3,3,3)] or [3,3[3]]. More complicated looping diagrams can also be expressed with care. The [[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|paracompact Coxeter group]] {{CDD|node|split1|branch|split2|node}} can be represented by Coxeter notation [(3,3,(3),3,3)], with nested/overlapping parentheses showing two adjacent [(3,3,3)] loops, and is also represented more compactly as [3[ ]×[ ]], representing the [[rhombus|rhombic symmetry]] of the Coxeter diagram. The paracompact complete graph diagram {{CDD|tet}} or {{CDD|branch|splitcross|branch}}, is represented as [3[3,3]] with the superscript [3,3] as the symmetry of its [[regular tetrahedron]] coxeter diagram. The Coxeter diagram usually leaves order-2 branches undrawn, but the bracket notation includes an explicit '''2''' to connect the subgraphs. So the Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node|3|node|2|node|3|node}} = ''A''2×''A''2 = 2''A''2 can be represented by [3]×[3] = [3]2 = [3,2,3]. Sometimes explicit 2-branches may be included either with a 2 label, or with a line with a gap: {{CDD|node|3|node|2x|node|3|node}} or {{CDD|node|3|node|3|2|3|node|3|node}}, as an identical presentation as [3,2,3]. {| |- valign=top | {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+ Finite groups |- ! Group

diagram]] |- | || [p,q]
with 2(p+q)with \frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}+\frac{1}{r}<1 || {{CDD|pqr}} |- | {\overline{BH}}_3||[4,3,5] || {{CDD|node|4|node|3|node|5|node}} |- | {\overline{K}}_3||[5,3,5] || {{CDD|node|5|node|3|node|5|node}} |- | {\overline{J}}_3, \tilde{H}_3||[3,5,3] || {{CDD|node|3|node|5|node|3|node}} |- | {\overline{DH}}_3||[5,31,1] || {{CDD|node|5|node|split1|nodes}} |- | {\widehat{AB}}_3 || [(3,3,3,4)] || {{CDD|label4|branch|3ab|branch}}  |- | {\widehat{AH}}_3 || [(3,3,3,5)] || {{CDD|label5|branch|3ab|branch}}  |- | {\widehat{BB}}_3 || [(3,4,3,4)] || {{CDD|label4|branch|3ab|branch|label4}} |- | {\widehat{BH}}_3 || [(3,4,3,5)] || {{CDD|label4|branch|3ab|branch|label5}} |- | {\widehat{HH}}_3 ||[(3,5,3,5)] || {{CDD|label5|branch|3ab|branch|label5}} |- | {\overline{H}}_4, \tilde{H}_4, H_5 || [3,3,3,5] || {{CDD|node|3|node|3|node|3|node|5|node}} |- | {\overline{BH}}_4 || [4,3,3,5] || {{CDD|node|4|node|3|node|3|node|5|node}} |- | {\overline{K}}_4 || [5,3,3,5] || {{CDD|node|5|node|3|node|3|node|5|node}} |- | {\overline{DH}}_4 || [5,3,31,1] || {{CDD|node|5|node|3|node|split1|nodes}} |- | {\widehat{AF}}_4 || [(3,3,3,3,4)] || {{CDD|label4|branch|3ab|nodes|split2|node}} |} |} For the affine and hyperbolic groups, the subscript is one less than the number of nodes in each case, since each of these groups was obtained by adding a node to a finite group's diagram. == Subgroups == Coxeter's notation represents rotational/translational symmetry by adding a '''+''' superscript operator outside the brackets, [X]+ which cuts the order of the group [X] in half, thus a index 2 subgroup. This operator implies an even number of operators must be applied, replacing reflections with rotations (or translations). When applied to a Coxeter group, this is called a '''direct subgroup''' because what remains are only direct isometries without reflective symmetry. The '''+''' operators can also be applied inside of the brackets, like [X,Y+] or [X,(Y,Z)+], and creates '''"semidirect" subgroups''' that may include both reflective and nonreflective generators. Semidirect subgroups can only apply to Coxeter group subgroups that have even order branches adjacent to it. Elements by parentheses inside of a Coxeter group can be give a '''+''' superscript operator, having the effect of dividing adjacent ordered branches into half order, thus is usually only applied with even numbers. For example, [4,3+] and [4,(3,3)+] ({{CDD|node|4|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}). If applied with adjacent odd branch, it doesn't create a subgroup of index 2, but instead creates overlapping fundamental domains, like [5,1+] = [5/2], which can define doubly wrapped polygons like a [[pentagram]], {5/2}, and [5,3+] relates to [[Schwarz triangle]] [5/2,3,3], [[polytope density|density]] 2. {| class=wikitable |+ Examples on Rank 2 groups !colspan=2|Group||Order||Generators||colspan=2|Subgroup||Order||Generators||Notes |- ||[''p'']||{{CDD|node_n0|p|node_n1}}||2''p''||{0,1}||[''p'']+||{{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h2}}||''p''||{01}||rowspan=2|Direct subgroup |- ||[2''p''+] = [2''p'']+||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|p|node_h2}}||2''p''||{01}||[2''p''+]+ = [2''p'']+2 = [''p'']+||{{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h2}}||''p''||{0101} |- |rowspan=3|[2''p''] |rowspan=3|{{CDD|node_n0|2x|p|node_n1}} |rowspan=3|4''p'' |rowspan=3|{0,1}||[1+,2''p''] = [''p'']||{{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node}} = {{CDD|node_h2|2x|p|node}} = {{CDD|node|p|node}}||rowspan=2|2''p''||{101,1}||rowspan=2|Half subgroups |- ||[2''p'',1+] = [''p'']||{{CDD|node|2x|p|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node|2x|p|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node|p|node}}||{0,010} |- ||[1+,2''p'',1+] = [2''p'']+2 = [''p'']+||{{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_h2|2|2x|p|2|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h2}}||''p''||{0101}||Quarter group |} Groups without neighboring '''+''' elements can be seen in ringed nodes Coxeter-Dynkin diagram for [[uniform polytope]]s and honeycomb are related to ''hole'' nodes around the '''+''' elements, empty circles with the alternated nodes removed. So the [[snub cube]], {{CDD|node_h|4|node_h|3|node_h}} has symmetry [4,3]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}), and the [[snub tetrahedron]], {{CDD|node|4|node_h|3|node_h}} has symmetry [4,3+] ({{CDD|node|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}), and a [[demicube]], h{4,3} = {3,3} ({{CDD|node_h|4|node|3|node}} or {{CDD|nodes_10ru|split2|node}} = {{CDD|node_1|3|node|3|node}}) has symmetry [1+,4,3] = [3,3] ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node|3|node}} or {{CDD|node_h0|4|node|3|node}} = {{CDD|nodes|split2|node}} = {{CDD|node|3|node|3|node}}). Note: [[Pyritohedral symmetry]] {{CDD|node|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}} can be written as {{CDD|node|4|2|node_h2|3|node_h2}}, separating the graph with gaps for clarity, with the generators {0,1,2} from the Coxeter group {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|3|node_n2}}, producing pyritohedral generators {0,12}, a reflection and 3-fold rotation. And chiral tetrahedral symmetry can be written as {{CDD|node_h0|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}} or {{CDD|node_h2|2|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}, [1+,4,3+] = [3,3]+, with generators {12,0120}. === Halving subgroups and extended groups === {{See|#Extended_symmetry}} {| class=wikitable align=right |+ Example halving operations |- |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 4.png|120px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 half1.png|120px]] |- align=center |{{CDD|node_c1|4|node_c3}}
[ 1,4, 1] = [4] |{{CDD|node_h0|4|node_c3}} = {{CDD|node_c3|2x|node_c3}} = {{CDD|node_c3|2|node_c3}}
[1+,4, 1]=[2]=[ ]×[ ] |- |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 half2.png|120px]] |[[File:Cyclic symmetry 4 half.png|120px]] |- align=center |{{CDD|node_c1|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_c1|2x|node_c1}} = {{CDD|node_c1|2|node_c1}}
[ 1,4,1+]=[2]=[ ]×[ ] |colspan=2|{{CDD|node_h0|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_h0|4|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h2}}
[1+,4,1+] = [2]+ |} Johnson extends the '''+''' operator to work with a placeholder 1+ nodes, which removes mirrors, doubling the size of the fundamental domain and cuts the group order in half.Johnson (2018), 11.6 ''Subgroups and extensions'', p 255, halving subgroups In general this operation only applies to individual mirrors bounded by even-order branches. The '''1''' represents a mirror so [2p] can be seen as [2p,1], [1,2p], or [1,2p,1], like diagram {{CDD|node|2x|p|node}} or {{CDD|node_c1|2x|p|node_c3}}, with 2 mirrors related by an order-2p dihedral angle. The effect of a mirror removal is to duplicate connecting nodes, which can be seen in the Coxeter diagrams: {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_c3}} = {{CDD|labelp|branch_c3}}, or in bracket notation:[1+,2p, 1] = [1,p,1] = [p]. Each of these mirrors can be removed so h[2p] = [1+,2p,1] = [1,2p,1+] = [p], a reflective subgroup index 2. This can be shown in a Coxeter diagram by adding a + symbol above the node: {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node}} = {{CDD|node|2x|p|node_h0}} = {{CDD|labelp|branch}}. If both mirrors are removed, a quarter subgroup is generated, with the branch order becoming a gyration point of half the order: :q[2p] = [1+,2p,1+] = [p]+, a rotational subgroup of index 4. {{CDD|node_h2|2|2x|p|2|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_h2}} = {{CDD|node_h2|2x|p|node_h0}} = {{CDD|labelp|branch_h2h2}}. For example, (with p=2): [4,1+] = [1+,4] = [2] = [ ]×[ ], order 4. [1+,4,1+] = [2]+, order 2. The opposite to halving is doubling which adds a mirror, bisecting a fundamental domain, and doubling the group order. : {{Brackets|p}} = [2p] Halving operations apply for higher rank groups, like [[tetrahedral symmetry]] is a half group of [[octahedral group]]: h[4,3] = [1+,4,3] = [3,3], removing half the mirrors at the 4-branch. The effect of a mirror removal is to duplicate all connecting nodes, which can be seen in the Coxeter diagrams: {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_c1|3|node_c2}} = {{CDD|labelp|branch_c1|split2|node_c2}}, h[2p,3] = [1+,2p,3] = [(p,3,3)]. If nodes are indexed, half subgroups can be labeled with new mirrors as composites. Like {{CDD|node_n0|2x|p|node_n1}}, generators {0,1} has subgroup {{CDD|node_h0|2x|p|node_n1}} = {{CDD|2_n0|node_n1|3_n0|p|node_n1}}, generators {1,010}, where mirror 0 is removed, and replaced by a copy of mirror 1 reflected across mirror 0. Also given {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|3|node_n2}}, generators {0,1,2}, it has half group {{CDD|node_h0|4|node_n1|3|node_n2}} = {{CDD|node_n1|3|node_n2|3|3_n0|node_n1|2_n0}}, generators {1,2,010}. Doubling by adding a mirror also applies in reversing the halving operation: {{Brackets|3,3}} = [4,3], or more generally {{Brackets|(q,q,p)}} = [2p,q]. {| class=wikitable ![[Tetrahedral symmetry]] ![[Octahedral symmetry]] |- align=center |[[File:Sphere symmetry group td.png|150px]]
Td, [3,3] = [1+,4,3]
{{CDD|node_c1|3|node_c1|3|node_c1}} = {{CDD|nodeab_c1|split2|node_c1}} = {{CDD|node_h0|4|node_c1|3|node_c1}}
(Order 24) |[[File:Sphere symmetry group oh.png|150px]]
Oh, [4,3] = {{Brackets|3,3}}
{{CDD|node_c2|4|node_c1|3|node_c1}}
(Order 48) |} === Radical subgroups === [[File:43-radial subgroups.png|thumb|A radical subgroup is similar to an alternation, but removes the rotational generators.]] Johnson also added an [[asterisk]] or star '''*''' operator for "radical" subgroupsJohnson (2018), 11.6 ''Subgroups and extensions'', p 259, radical subgroup, that acts similar to the + operator, but removes rotational symmetry. The index of the radical subgroup is the order of the removed element. For example, [4,3*] ≅ [2,2]. The removed [3] subgroup is order 6 so [2,2] is an index 6 subgroup of [4,3]. The radical subgroups represent the inverse operation to an [[#Extended symmetry|extended symmetry]] operation. For example, [4,3*] ≅ [2,2], and in reverse [2,2] can be extended as [3[2,2]] ≅ [4,3]. The subgroups can be expressed as a Coxeter diagram: {{CDD|node_c1|4|node|3s|node}} or {{CDD|node_c1|4|node_x|3|node_x}} ≅ {{CDD|nodeab_c1|2|node_c1}}. The removed node (mirror) causes adjacent mirror virtual mirrors to become real mirrors. If [4,3] has generators {0,1,2}, [4,3+], index 2, has generators {0,12}; [1+,4,3] ≅ [3,3], index 2 has generators {010,1,2}; while radical subgroup [4,3*] ≅ [2,2], index 6, has generators {01210, 2, (012)3}; and finally [1+,4,3*], index 12 has generators {0(12)20, (012)201}. {{Clear}} === Trionic subgroups === [[File:Trionic subgroups hexagonal symmetry.png|120px|thumb|left|Rank 2 example, [6] trionic subgroups with 3 colors of mirror lines]] [[File:432 trionic subgroups.png|thumb|Example on octahedral symmetry: [4,3⅄] = [2,4].]] [[File:Trionic subgroups hexagonal.png|thumb|Example trionic subgroup on hexagonal symmetry [6,3] maps onto a larger [6,3] symmetry.]] [[File:Trionic Coxeter groups rank 3.png|120px|thumb|left|Rank 3]] [[File:Hyperbolic 832 trionic subgroup 842.png|thumb|Example trionic subgroups on octagonal symmetry [8,3] maps onto larger [4,8] symmetries.]] [[File:Trionic subgroups rank 4b.png|120px|thumb|left|Rank 4]] A '''trionic subgroup''' is an index 3 subgroups. There are many Johnson defines a ''trionic subgroup'' with operator ⅄, index 3. For rank 2 Coxeter groups, [3], the trionic subgroup, [3⅄] is [ ], a single mirror. And for [3''p''], the trionic subgroup is [3''p'']⅄ ≅ [''p'']. Given {{CDD|node_n0|3x|p|node_n1}}, with generators {0,1}, has 3 trionic subgroups. They can be differentiated by putting the ⅄ symbol next to the mirror generator to be removed, or on a branch for both: [3''p'',1⅄] = {{CDD|node_n0|3x|p|node_trionic}} = {{CDD|node_n0|p|3_n1|3_n0|node_n1|2_n0|2_n1}}, {{CDD|node_trionic|3x|p|node_n1}} = {{CDD|2_n0|2_n1|node_n0|3_n1|3_n0|p|node_n1}}, and [3''p''⅄] = {{CDD|node_n0|3x|3trionic|p|node_n1}} = {{CDD|2_n0|node_n1|3_n0|p|3_n1|node_n0|2_n1}} with generators {0,10101}, {01010,1}, or {101,010}. [[#Trionic subgroups of tetrahedral symmetry|Trionic subgroups of tetrahedral symmetry]]: [3,3]⅄ ≅ [2+,4], relating the symmetry of the [[regular tetrahedron]] and [[tetragonal disphenoid]]. For rank 3 Coxeter groups, [''p'',3], there is a trionic subgroup [''p'',3⅄] ≅ [''p''/2,''p''], or {{CDD|node_n0|2x|p|node_n1|3trionic|node_n2}} = {{CDD|2_n2|2_n1|node_n0|3_n1|3_n2|p|node_n0|2x|p|node_n1}}. For example the finite group [4,3⅄] ≅ [2,4], and Euclidean group [6,3⅄] ≅ [3,6], and hyperbolic group [8,3⅄] ≅ [4,8]. An odd-order adjacent branch, ''p'', will not lower the group order, but create overlapping fundamental domains. The group order stays the same, while the [[density (polytope)|density]] increases. For example the [[icosahedral symmetry]], [5,3], of the regular polyhedra [[icosahedron]] becomes [5/2,5], the symmetry of 2 regular star polyhedra. It also relates the hyperbolic tilings {p,3}, and [[List_of_regular_polytopes_and_compounds#Hyperbolic_star-tilings|star hyperbolic tilings]] {p/2,p} For rank 4, [''q'',2''p'',3⅄] = [2''p'',((p,q,q))], {{CDD|node|q|node|2x|p|node|3trionic|node}} = {{CDD|labelq|branch|split2-pq|node|2x|p|node}}. For example [3,4,3⅄] = [4,3,3], or {{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|4|node_n2|3trionic|node_n3}} = {{CDD|2_n3|2_n2|node_n1|3_n2|3_n3|3|node_n0|3|node_n1|4|node_n2}}, generators {0,1,2,3} in [3,4,3] with the trionic subgroup [4,3,3] generators {0,1,2,32123}. For hyperbolic groups, [3,6,3⅄] = [6,3[3]], and [4,4,3⅄] = [4,4,4]. {{-}} ==== Trionic subgroups of tetrahedral symmetry==== [[File:Trionic_subgroups_of_tetrahedral_symmetry_stereographic_projection.png|thumb|left|[3,3]⅄ ≅ [2+,4] as one of 3 sets of 2 orthogonal mirrors in [[stereographic projection]]. The red, green, and blue represent 3 sets of mirrors, and the gray lines are removed mirrors, leaving 2-fold gyrations (purple diamonds).]] [[File:33-trionic subgroups.png|thumb|Trionic relations of [3,3]]] Johnson identified two specific '''trionic subgroups'''Johnson (2018), 11.6 ''Subgroups and extensions'', p 258, trionic subgroups of [3,3], first an index 3 subgroup [3,3]⅄ ≅ [2+,4], with [3,3] ({{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|3|node_n2}} = {{CDD|node|split1|nodes}} = {{CDD|node|split1|branch|label2}}) generators {0,1,2}. It can also be written as [(3,3,2⅄)] ({{CDD|node|split1|2|branch_h2h2|label2}}) as a reminder of its generators {02,1}. This symmetry reduction is the relationship between the regular [[tetrahedron]] and the [[tetragonal disphenoid]], represent a stretching of a tetrahedron perpendicular to two opposite edges. Secondly he identifies a related index 6 subgroup [3,3]Δ or [(3,3,2⅄)]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|split1|2|branch_h2h2|label2}}), index 3 from [3,3]+ ≅ [2,2]+, with generators {02,1021}, from [3,3] and its generators {0,1,2}. These subgroups also apply within larger Coxeter groups with [3,3] subgroup with neighboring branches all even order. [[File:334 trionic subgroups2.png|thumb|Trionic subgroup relations of [3,3,4]]] For example, [(3,3)+,4], [(3,3)⅄,4], and [(3,3)Δ,4] are subgroups of [3,3,4], index 2, 3 and 6 respectively. The generators of [(3,3)⅄,4] ≅ {{Brackets|4,2,4}} ≅ [8,2+,8], order 128, are {02,1,3} from [3,3,4] generators {0,1,2,3}. And [(3,3)Δ,4] ≅ {{Brackets|4,2+,4}}, order 64, has generators {02,1021,3}. As well, [3⅄,4,3⅄] ≅ [(3,3)⅄,4]. Also related [31,1,1] = [3,3,4,1+] has trionic subgroups: [31,1,1]⅄ = [(3,3)⅄,4,1+], order 64, and 1=[31,1,1]Δ = [(3,3)Δ,4,1+] ≅ [[4,2+,4]]+, order 32. {{Clear}} === Central inversion=== [[File:Point Reflection.png|thumb|A 2D central inversion is a 180 degree rotation, [2]+]] A [[central inversion]], order 2, is operationally differently by dimension. The group [ ]''n'' = [2''n''-1] represents ''n'' orthogonal mirrors in n-dimensional space, or an [[n-flat]] subspace of a higher dimensional space. The mirrors of the group [2''n''-1] are numbered {{tmath|0 \dots n-1}}. The order of the mirrors doesn't matter in the case of an inversion. The matrix of a central inversion is {{tmath|-I}}, the Identity matrix with negative one on the diagonal. From that basis, the central inversion has a generator as the product of all the orthogonal mirrors. In Coxeter notation this inversion group is expressed by adding an alternation + to each 2 branch. The alternation symmetry is marked on Coxeter diagram nodes as open nodes. A [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]] can be marked up with explicit 2 branches defining a linear sequence of mirrors, open-nodes, and shared double-open nodes to show the chaining of the reflection generators. For example, [2+,2] and [2,2+] are subgroups index 2 of [2,2], {{CDD|node|2|node|2|node}}, and are represented as {{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h2|2|node}} (or {{CDD|node_h2|3|2|3|node_h2|2|node}}) and {{CDD|node|2|node_h2|2x|node_h2}} (or {{CDD|node|2|node_h2|3|2|3|node_h2}}) with generators {01,2} and {0,12} respectively. Their common subgroup index 4 is [2+,2+], and is represented by {{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}} (or {{CDD|node_h2|3|2|3|node_h4|3|2|3|node_h2}}), with the double-open {{CDD|node_h4}} marking a shared node in the two alternations, and a single [[rotoreflection]] generator {012}. {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" ! Dimension ! Coxeter notation ! Order ! Coxeter diagram ! Operation ! Generator |- |2||[2]+||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h2}}||180° [[Rotation (mathematics)|rotation]], C2||{01} |- |3||[2+,2+]||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||[[rotoreflection]], Ci or S2||{012} |- |4||[2+,2+,2+]||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||[[double rotation]]||{0123} |- |5||[2+,2+,2+,2+]||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||double rotary reflection||{01234} |- |6||[2+,2+,2+,2+,2+]||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||triple rotation||{012345} |- |7||[2+,2+,2+,2+,2+,2+]||2||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||triple rotary reflection||{0123456} |} === Rotations and rotary reflections === Rotations and [[rotary reflection]]s are constructed by a single single-generator product of all the reflections of a prismatic group, [2''p'']×[2''q'']×... where [[Greatest common divisor|gcd]](''p'',''q'',...)=1, they are isomorphic to the abstract [[cyclic group]] Zn, of order ''n''=2''pq''. The 4-dimensional double rotations, [2''p''+,2+,2''q''+] (with [[Greatest common divisor|gcd]](''p'',''q'')=1), which include a central group, and are expressed by Conway as ±[C''p''×C''q'']Conway, 2003, p.46, Table 4.2 Chiral groups II, order 2''pq''. From Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node_n0|2x|p|node_n1|2|node_n2|2x|q|node_n3}}, generators {0,1,2,3}, the single generator of [2''p''+,2+,2''q''+], {{CDD|node_h2|2x|p|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|q|node_h2}} is {0123}. The half group, [2''p''+,2+,2''q''+]+, or cyclc graph, [(2''p''+,2+,2''q''+,2+)], {{CDD|3|node_h4|2x|p|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|q|node_h4|2x}} expressed by Conway is [C''p''×C''q''], order ''pq'', with generator {01230123}. If there is a common factor ''f'', the double rotation can be written as {{frac|1|''f''}}[2''pf''+,2+,2''qf''+] (with [[Greatest common divisor|gcd]](''p'',''q'')=1), generator {0123}, order 2''pqf''. For example, ''p''=''q''=1, ''f''=2, {{frac|1|2}}[4+,2+,4+] is order 4. And {{frac|1|''f''}}[2''pf''+,2+,2''qf''+]+, generator {01230123}, is order ''pqf''. For example {{frac|1|2}}[4+,2+,4+]+ is order 2, a [[central inversion]]. {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" |+ Examples ! Dimension ! Coxeter notation ! Order ! Coxeter diagram ! order ''pqr''
gcd(''p'',''q'',''r'')=1 |- !7 ||[2''p''+,2+,2''q''+,2+,2''r''+,2+]||{{CDD|node_h2|2x|p|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|q|node_h4|2x|node_h4|2x|r|node_h4|2x|node_h2}}||triple rotary reflection||{0123456}||[2''p''+,2+,2''q''+,2+,2''r''+,2+]+ |} === Commutator subgroups === Simple groups with only odd-order branch elements have only a single rotational/translational subgroup of order 2, which is also the [[commutator subgroup]], examples [3,3]+, [3,5]+, [3,3,3]+, [3,3,5]+. For other Coxeter groups with even-order branches, the commutator subgroup has index 2''c'', where c is the number of disconnected subgraphs when all the even-order branches are removed.Coxeter and Moser, 1980, Sec 9.5 Commutator subgroup, p. 124–126 For example, [4,4] has three independent nodes in the Coxeter diagram when the '''4'''s are removed, so its commutator subgroup is index 23, and can have different representations, all with three '''+''' operators: [4+,4+]+, [1+,4,1+,4,1+], [1+,4,4,1+]+, or [(4+,4+,2+)]. A general notation can be used with +''c'' as a group exponent, like [4,4]+3. === Example subgroups === ==== Rank 2 example subgroups ==== [[Dihedral symmetry]] groups with even-orders have a number of subgroups. This example shows two generator mirrors of [4] in red and green, and looks at all subgroups by halfing, rank-reduction, and their direct subgroups. The group [4], {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1}} has two mirror generators 0, and 1. Each generate two virtual mirrors 101 and 010 by reflection across the other. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12| Subgroups of [4] |- ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=2|2 (half) !colspan=2|4 (Rank-reduction) |- !Diagram |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 4.png|120px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 half1.png|120px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 half2.png|120px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 quarter1.png|120px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry 4 quarter2.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter

[ ]+ |- align=center !Generators |{01} |colspan=2|{(01)2} |colspan=2|{02} = {12} = {(01)4} = { } |} ==== Rank 3 Euclidean example subgroups ==== The [4,4] group has 15 small index subgroups. This table shows them all, with a yellow fundamental domain for pure reflective groups, and alternating white and blue domains which are paired up to make rotational domains. Cyan, red, and green mirror lines correspond to the same colored nodes in the Coxeter diagram. Subgroup generators can be expressed as products of the original 3 mirrors of the fundamental domain, {0,1,2}, corresponding to the 3 nodes of the Coxeter diagram, {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|4|node_n2}}. A product of two intersecting reflection lines makes a rotation, like {012}, {12}, or {02}. Removing a mirror causes two copies of neighboring mirrors, across the removed mirror, like {010}, and {212}. Two rotations in series cut the rotation order in half, like {0101} or {(01)2}, {1212} or {(02)2}. A product of all three mirrors creates a [[transreflection]], like {012} or {120}. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="text-align:center;" !colspan=12| Small index subgroups of [4,4] |- ! (222222) |} == Extended symmetry== {| class=wikitable align=right width=100 |{{A2 honeycombs}} |- |In the Euclidean plane, the {\tilde{A}}_2, [3[3]] Coxeter group can be extended in two ways into the {\tilde{G}}_2, [6,3] Coxeter group and relates uniform tilings as ringed diagrams. |} {{See also|Goursat tetrahedron#Extended symmetry}} Coxeter's notation includes double square bracket notation, {{Brackets|X}} to express [[automorphism|automorphic]] symmetry within a Coxeter diagram. Johnson added alternative of angled-bracket <[X]> or {{langle}}[X]{{rangle}} option as equivalent to square brackets for doubling to distinguish diagram symmetry through the nodes versus through the branches. Johnson also added a prefix symmetry modifier [Y[X]], where Y can either represent symmetry of the Coxeter diagram of [X], or symmetry of the fundamental domain of [X]. For example, in 3D these equivalent [[rectangle]] and [[Rhombus|rhombic]] geometry diagrams of {\tilde{A}}_3: {{CDD|branch|3ab|3ab|branch}} and {{CDD|node|split1|nodes|split2|node}}, the first doubled with square brackets, {{Brackets|3[4]}} or twice doubled as [2[3[4]]], with [2], order 4 higher symmetry. To differentiate the second, angled brackets are used for doubling, {{langle}}[3[4]]{{rangle}} and twice doubled as {{langle}}2[3[4]]{{rangle}}, also with a different [2], order 4 symmetry. Finally a full symmetry where all 4 nodes are equivalent can be represented by [4[3[4]]], with the order 8, [4] symmetry of the [[Square (geometry)|square]]. But by considering the [[tetragonal disphenoid]] fundamental domain the [4] extended symmetry of the square graph can be marked more explicitly as [(2+,4)[3[4]]] or [2+,4[3[4]]]. Further symmetry exists in the cyclic {\tilde{A}}_n and branching D_3, {\tilde{E}}_6, and {\tilde{D}}_4 diagrams. {\tilde{A}}_n has order 2''n'' symmetry of a regular ''n''-gon, {''n''}, and is represented by [''n''[3[''n'']]]. D_3 and {\tilde{E}}_6 are represented by [3[31,1,1]] = [3,4,3] and [3[32,2,2]] respectively while {\tilde{D}}_4 by [(3,3)[31,1,1,1]] = [3,3,4,3], with the diagram containing the order 24 symmetry of the regular [[tetrahedron]], {3,3}. The paracompact hyperbolic group {\bar{L}}_5 = [31,1,1,1,1], {{CDD|node|branch3|splitsplit2|node|split1|nodes}}, contains the symmetry of a [[5-cell]], {3,3,3}, and thus is represented by [(3,3,3)[31,1,1,1,1]] = [3,4,3,3,3]. An [[asterisk]] * superscript is effectively an inverse operation, creating ''radical subgroups'' removing connected of odd-ordered mirrors.Norman W. Johnson, Asia Ivić Weiss, ''Quaternionic modular groups'', Linear Algebra and its Applications, Volume 295, Issues 1–3, 1 July 1999, Pages 159–189 [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S002437959900107X] Examples: {| class="wikitable collapsible" !colspan=12|Example Extended groups and radical subgroups |- valign=top | {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" ! |} Looking at generators, the double symmetry is seen as adding a new operator that maps symmetric positions in the Coxeter diagram, making some original generators redundant. For 3D [[space group]]s, and 4D point groups, Coxeter defines an index two subgroup of {{Brackets|X}}, {{Brackets|X|+}}, which he defines as the product of the original generators of [X] by the doubling generator. This looks similar to {{Brackets|X}}+, which is the chiral subgroup of {{Brackets|X}}. So for example the 3D space groups {{Brackets|4,3,4}}+ (I432, 211) and {{Brackets|4,3,4|+}} (Pm{{overline|3}}n, 223) are distinct subgroups of {{Brackets|4,3,4}} (Im{{overline|3}}m, 229). == Computation with reflection matrices as symmetry generators == A Coxeter group, represented by [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_n0|p|node_n1|q|node_n2}}, is given Coxeter notation [p,q] for the branch orders. Each node in the Coxeter diagram represents a mirror, by convention called ρi (and matrix Ri). The ''generators'' of this group [p,q] are reflections: ρ0, ρ1, and ρ2. Rotational subsymmetry is given as products of reflections: By convention, σ0,1 (and matrix S0,1) = ρ0ρ1 represents a rotation of angle π/p, and σ1,2 = ρ1ρ2 is a rotation of angle π/q, and σ0,2 = ρ0ρ2 represents a rotation of angle π/2. [p,q]+, {{CDD|node_h2|3_n0|3_n1|p|node_h2|3|q|3_n1|3_n2|node_h2}}, is an index 2 subgroup represented by two rotation generators, each a products of two reflections: σ0,1, σ1,2, and representing rotations of π/''p'', and π/''q'' angles respectively. With one even branch, [''p''+,2''q''], {{CDD|node_h2|3_n0|3_n1|p|node_h2|2x|q|node_n2}} or {{CDD|node_h2|3_n0|3_n1|p|node_h2|2|2x|q|node_n2}}, is another subgroup of index 2, represented by rotation generator σ0,1, and reflectional ρ2. With even branches, [2''p''+,2''q''+], {{CDD|node_h2|3_n0|3_n1|3_n2|2x|p|node_h4|2x|q|node_h2}}, is a subgroup of index 4 with two generators, constructed as a product of all three reflection matrices: By convention as: ψ0,1,2 and ψ1,2,0, which are [[rotary reflection]]s, representing a reflection and rotation or reflection. In the case of affine Coxeter groups like {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|4|node_n2}}, or {{CDD|node_n0|infin|node_n1}}, one mirror, usually the last, is translated off the origin. A [[translation (mathematics)|translation]] generator τ0,1 (and matrix T0,1) is constructed as the product of two (or an even number of) reflections, including the affine reflection. A [[transreflection]] (reflection plus a translation) can be the product of an odd number of reflections φ0,1,2 (and matrix V0,1,2), like the index 4 subgroup {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|4|node_n2}}: [4+,4+] = {{CDD|node_h2|3_n0|3_n1|3_n2|4|node_h4|4|node_h2}}. Another composite generator, by convention as ζ (and matrix Z), represents the [[Inversion in a point|inversion]], mapping a point to its inverse. For [4,3] and [5,3], ζ = (ρ0ρ1ρ2)h/2, where ''h'' is 6 and 10 respectively, the [[Coxeter number]] for each family. For 3D Coxeter group [p,q] ({{CDD|node|p|node|q|node}}), this subgroup is a rotary reflection [2+,h+]. Coxeter groups are categorized by their rank, being the number of nodes in its [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]]. The structure of the groups are also given with their abstract group types: In this article, the abstract [[dihedral group]]s are represented as ''Dih''n, and [[cyclic group]]s are represented by ''Z''n, with ''Dih''1=''Z''2. === Rank 2 === Example, in 2D, the Coxeter group [p] ({{CDD|node|p|node}}) is represented by two reflection matrices R0 and R1, The cyclic symmetry [p]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h2}}) is represented by rotation generator of matrix S0,1. {| |- valign=top | {| class=wikitable |+ [p], {{CDD|node_n0|p|node_n1}} ! !colspan=2|Reflections !Rotation |- !Name ! {{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2}} |- align=center !Order |2||2||4 |- !Matrix | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] |} |} === Rank 3 === The finite rank 3 Coxeter groups are [1,''p''], [2,''p''], [3,3], [3,4], and [3,5]. To reflect a point through a plane ax + by + cz = 0 (which goes through the origin), one can use \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{I}-2\mathbf{NN}^T , where \mathbf{I} is the 3x3 identity matrix and \mathbf{N} is the three-dimensional [[unit vector]] for the vector normal of the plane. If the [[L2 norm]] of a, b, and c is unity, the transformation matrix can be expressed as: :\mathbf{A} = \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 1 - 2 a^2 & - 2 a b & - 2 a c \\ - 2 a b & 1 - 2 b^2 & - 2 b c \\ - 2 a c & - 2 b c & 1 - 2c^2 \end{smallmatrix}\right ] ==== Dihedral symmetry==== The reducible 3-dimensional finite reflective group is [[dihedral symmetry]], [''p'',2], order 4''p'', {{CDD|node_n0|p|node_n1|2|node_n2}}. The reflection generators are matrices R0, R1, R2. R02=R12=R22=(R0×R1)3=(R1×R2)3=(R0×R2)2=Identity. [''p'',2]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h2|2x|node_h2}}) is generated by 2 of 3 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, and S0,2. An order ''p'' [[rotoreflection]] is generated by V0,1,2, the product of all 3 reflections. {| class=wikitable |+ [p,2], {{CDD|node_n0|p|node_n1|2|node_n2}} ! !colspan=3|Reflections !colspan=3|Rotation !Rotoreflection |- !Name ! R0 ! R1 ! R2 ! S0,1 ! S1,2 ! S0,2 ! V0,1,2 |- align=center !Group |{{CDD|node_n0}} |{{CDD|node_n1}} |{{CDD|node_n2}} |{{CDD|node_h2|p|node_h}} |colspan=2|{{CDD|node_h2|3|2|3|node_h2}} |{{CDD|node_h|2x|p|node_h4|3|2|3|node_h2}} |- align=center !Order |2||2||2||''p''||colspan=2|2||2''p'' |- !Matrix | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & -1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} \cos 2\pi/p & \sin 2\pi/p & 0 \\ \sin 2\pi/p & -\cos 2\pi/p & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} \cos 2\pi/p & \sin 2\pi/p & 0 \\ -\sin 2\pi/p & \cos 2\pi/p & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} \cos 2\pi/p & \sin 2\pi/p & 0 \\ -\sin 2\pi/p & \cos 2\pi/p & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & -1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & -1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] | \left [\begin{smallmatrix} \cos 2\pi/p & -\sin 2\pi/p & 0 \\ -\sin 2\pi/p & -\cos 2\pi/p & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1\\ \end{smallmatrix}\right ] |} ==== Tetrahedral symmetry==== [[File:Sphere symmetry group td.png|thumb|reflection lines for [3,3] = {{CDD|node_c1|3|node_c1|3|node_c1}}]] The simplest irreducible 3-dimensional finite reflective group is [[tetrahedral symmetry]], [3,3], order 24, {{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|3|node_n2}}. The reflection generators, from a D3=A3 construction, are matrices R0, R1, R2. R02=R12=R22=(R0×R1)3=(R1×R2)3=(R0×R2)2=Identity. [3,3]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 2 of 3 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, and S0,2. A [[#trionic subgroup|trionic subgroup]], isomorphic to [2+,4], order 8, is generated by S0,2 and R1. An order 4 [[rotoreflection]] is generated by V0,1,2, the product of all 3 reflections. {| class=wikitable |+ [3,3], {{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|3|node_n2}} ! !colspan=3|Reflections !colspan=3|Rotations !Rotoreflection |- !Name ! The reflection generators matrices are R0, R1, R2. R02=R12=R22=(R0×R1)4=(R1×R2)3=(R0×R2)2=Identity. Chiral octahedral symmetry, [4,3]+, ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 2 of 3 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, and S0,2. [[Pyritohedral symmetry]] [4,3+], ({{CDD|node_n0|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by reflection R0 and rotation S1,2. A 6-fold [[rotoreflection]] is generated by V0,1,2, the product of all 3 reflections. {| class=wikitable |+ [4,3], {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|3|node_n2}} ! !colspan=3|Reflections !colspan=3|Rotations !Rotoreflection |- !Name ! The reflection generators matrices are R0, R1, R2. R02=R12=R22=(R0×R1)5=(R1×R2)3=(R0×R2)2=Identity. [5,3]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 2 of 3 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, and S0,2. [4,4]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2|4|node_h2}}) (p4) is generated by S0,1 S1,2, and S0,2. [4+,4+] ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h4|4|node_h2}}) (pgg) is generated by 2-fold rotation S0,2 and transreflection V0,1,2. [4+,4] ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2|4|node}}) (p4g) is generated by S0,1 and R3. The group [(4,4,2+)] ({{CDD|node|split1-44|branch_h2h2|label2}}) (cmm), is generated by 2-fold rotation S1,3 and reflection R2. {| class=wikitable |+ [4,4], {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|4|node_n2}} ! !colspan=3|Reflections !colspan=3|Rotations !Rotoreflection |- !Name ! The reflection generators matrices are R0, R1, R2, R3. R02=R12=R22=R32=(R0×R1)4=(R1×R2)3=(R2×R3)3=(R0×R2)2=(R1×R3)2=(R0×R3)2=Identity. Chiral hyperoctahedral symmetry, [4,3,3]+, ({{CDD|node_h2|4|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 3 of 6 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, S2,3, S0,2, S1,3, and S0,3. [[Hyperpyritohedral symmetry]] [4,(3,3)+], ({{CDD|node_n0|4|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by reflection R0 and rotations S1,2 and S2,3. An 8-fold [[double rotation]] is generated by W0,1,2,3, the product of all 4 reflections. {| class=wikitable |+ [4,3,3], {{CDD|node_n0|4|node_n1|3|node_n2|3|node_n3}} ! !colspan=4|Reflections !colspan=6|Rotations !colspan=4|Rotoreflection !Double rotation |- !Name ! |(0,0,1,-1)n |(0,1,-1,0)n |(1,-1,0,0)n | | | | |} ==== Icositetrachoric symmetry==== A irreducible 4-dimensional finite reflective group is [[Icositetrachoric group]] (for [[24-cell]]), F4=[3,4,3], order 1152, {{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|4|node_n2|3|node_n3}}. The reflection generators matrices are R0, R1, R2, R3. R02=R12=R22=R32=(R0×R1)3=(R1×R2)4=(R2×R3)3=(R0×R2)2=(R1×R3)2=(R0×R3)2=Identity. Chiral icositetrachoric symmetry, [3,4,3]+, ({{CDD|node_h2|3|node_h2|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 3 of 6 rotations: S0,1, S1,2, S2,3, S0,2, S1,3, and S0,3. Ionic diminished [3,4,3+] group, ({{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|4|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by reflection R0 and rotations S1,2 and S2,3. An 12-fold [[double rotation]] is generated by W0,1,2,3, the product of all 4 reflections. {| class=wikitable |+ [3,4,3], {{CDD|node_n0|3|node_n1|4|node_n2|3|node_n3}} ! !colspan=4|Reflections !colspan=6|Rotations !colspan=4|Rotoreflection !Double rotation |- !Name ! ==== Hypericosahedral symmetry==== The hyper-icosahedral symmetry, [5,3,3], order 14400, {{CDD|node_n0|5|node_n1|3|node_n2|3|node_n3}}. The reflection generators matrices are R0, R1, R2, R3. R02=R12=R22=R32=(R0×R1)5=(R1×R2)3=(R2×R3)3=(R0×R2)2=(R0×R3)2=(R1×R3)2=Identity. [5,3,3]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2|3|node_h2}}) is generated by 3 rotations: S0,1 = R0×R1, S1,2 = R1×R2, S2,3 = R2×R3, etc. {| class=wikitable |+ [5,3,3], {{CDD|node_n0|5|node_n1|3|node_n2|3|node_n3}} ! !colspan=4|Reflections |- !Name ! R0 ! R1 ! R2 ! It is represented as a [[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram]] with a single node, {{CDD|node}}. The ''[[identity group]]'' is the direct subgroup [ ]+, Z1, symmetry order 1. The '''+''' superscript simply implies that alternate mirror reflections are ignored, leaving the identity group in this simplest case. Coxeter used a single open node to represent an alternation, {{CDD|node_h2}}. {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" ! Group ! Coxeter notation ! [[Coxeter diagram]] ! Order ! Description |- ||C1||[ ]+||{{CDD|node_h2}}||1||Identity |- ||D1||[ ]||{{CDD|node}}||2||Reflection group |} == Rank two groups== {{Further information|Point groups in two dimensions}} [[File:Regular hexagon symmetries2.png|400px|thumb|A regular [[hexagon]], with markings on edges and vertices has 8 symmetries: [6], [3], [2], [1], [6]+, [3]+, [2]+, [1]+, with [3] and [1] existing in two forms, depending whether the mirrors are on the edges or vertices.]] In two dimensions, the ''[[rectangle|rectangular]] group'' [2], abstract ''D''12 or ''D''2, also can be represented as a [[direct product]] [ ]×[ ], being the product of two bilateral groups, represents two orthogonal mirrors, with Coxeter diagram, {{CDD|node|2|node}}, with [[Order (group theory)|order]] 4. The '''2''' in [2] comes from linearization of the orthogonal subgraphs in the Coxeter diagram, as {{CDD|node|2x|node}} with explicit branch order 2. The ''rhombic group'', [2]+ ({{CDD|node_h2|2x|node_h2}} or {{CDD|node_h2|3|2|3|node_h2}}), half of the rectangular group, the [[point reflection]] symmetry, Z2, order 2. Coxeter notation to allow a '''1''' place-holder for lower rank groups, so [1] is the same as [ ], and [1+] or [1]+ is the same as [ ]+ and Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node_h2}}. The ''full p-gonal group'' [p], abstract ''[[dihedral group]]'' Dp, ([[Nonabelian group|nonabelian]] for p>2), of [[Order (group theory)|order]] 2''p'', is generated by two mirrors at angle ''π''/''p'', represented by Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node|p|node}}. The ''p-gonal'' subgroup [p]+, ''[[cyclic group]]'' ''Z''''p'', of order ''p'', generated by a rotation angle of ''π''/''p''. Coxeter notation uses double-bracking to represent an [[automorphism|automorphic]] ''doubling'' of symmetry by adding a bisecting mirror to the [[fundamental domain]]. For example, [[p]] adds a bisecting mirror to [p], and is isomorphic to [2p]. In the limit, going down to one dimensions, the ''full [[apeirogon]]al group'' is obtained when the angle goes to zero, so [∞], abstractly the [[infinite dihedral group]] D∞, represents two parallel mirrors and has a Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node|infin|node}}. The ''[[One-dimensional symmetry group#Translational symmetry|apeirogonal group]]'' [∞]+, {{CDD|node_h2|infin|node_h2}}, abstractly the infinite [[cyclic group]] Z∞, [[isomorphism|isomorphic]] to the ''additive group'' of the [[integers]], is generated by a single nonzero translation. In the hyperbolic plane, there is a ''full [[pseudogon]]al group'' [''iπ/λ''], and ''pseudogonal subgroup'' [''iπ/λ'']+, {{CDD|node_h2|ultra|node_h2}}. These groups exist in regular infinite-sided polygons, with edge length λ. The mirrors are all orthogonal to a single line. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12|Example rank 2 finite and hyperbolic symmetries |- !Type !colspan=5|Finite !Affine !colspan=5|Hyperbolic |- align=center !Geometry |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 1.png|80px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 2.png|80px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 3.png|80px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains 4.png|80px]] |... |[[File:Dihedral symmetry domains infinity.png|80px]] |[[File:Horocycle mirrors.png|80px]] |[[File:Dihedral symmetry ultra.png|80px]] |- align=center !Coxeter |{{CDD|node_c1}}
