{{Infobox artwork/wikidata|location=[[Van Gogh Museum]]}} '''''Sunflowers''''' (original title, in French: '''''Tournesols''''') is the name of two [[serial imagery|series]] of [[still life]] paintings by the Dutch painter [[Vincent van Gogh]]. The first series, executed in Paris in 1887, depicts the flowers lying on the ground, while the second set, executed a year later in [[Arles]], shows a bouquet of sunflowers in a vase. In the artist's mind both sets were linked by the name of his friend [[Paul Gauguin]], who acquired two of the Paris versions. About eight months later van Gogh hoped to welcome and to impress Gauguin again with ''Sunflowers'', now part of the painted ''[[Décoration for the Yellow House]]'' that he prepared for the guestroom of his home in Arles, where Gauguin was supposed to stay. After Gauguin's departure, van Gogh imagined the two major versions as wings of the ''Berceuse Triptych'', and finally he included them in his [[Vincent van Gogh's display at Les XX, 1890|Les XX in Bruxelles exhibit]]. == The Paris ''Sunflowers'' == {{See also|Still life paintings by Vincent van Gogh (Paris)}} Little is known of Van Gogh's activities during the two years he lived with his brother, Theo, in Paris, 1886–1888. The fact that he had painted ''Sunflowers'' already is only revealed in the spring of 1889, when Gauguin claimed one of the Arles versions in exchange for studies he had left behind after leaving Arles for Paris. Van Gogh was upset and replied that Gauguin had absolutely no right to make this request: "I am definitely keeping my sunflowers in question. He has two of them already, let that hold him. And if he is not satisfied with the exchange he has made with me, he can take back his little Martinique canvas, and his self-portrait sent me from Brittany,Wildenstein at the same time giving me back both my portraitSelfportrait ''à l'ami Gauguin'' and the two sunflower canvases which he has taken to Paris. So if he ever broaches this subject again, I've told you just how matters stand."{{cite web|url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/19/571.htm|title=Letter 571 - Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh : 17 January 1889|publisher=}} {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = | header_background = | footer = F.Numbers refer to [[Jacob Baart de la Faille|De la Faille Catalogue raisonné]] | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Van Gogh - Zwei abgeschnittene Sonnenblumen.jpeg | width1 = 120 | caption1 = ''Sunflowers'', study (F377), Oil on canvas, 21 x 27 cm, [[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam | image2 = Vincent van Gogh - Sunflowers (Metropolitan Museum of Art).jpg | width2 = 130 | caption2 = ''Sunflowers'' (F375), Oil on canvas, 43.2 x 61 cm, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York | image3 = Van Gogh - Zwei abgeschnittene Sonnenblumen1.jpeg | width3 = 113 | caption3 = ''Sunflowers'' (F376), Oil on canvas, 50 x 60.7 cm, [[Museum of Fine Arts Bern]] | image4 = Four Withered Sunflowers.jpg | width4 = 153 | caption4 = ''Sunflowers'' (F452), Oil on canvas, 60 × 100 cm, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], Otterlo }} The two ''Sunflowers'' in question show two buttons each; one of them was preceded by a small study, and a fourth large canvas combines both compositions. These were Van Gogh's first paintings with ''"nothing but sunflowers"''—yet, he had already included sunflowers in still life and landscape earlier. [[File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 123.jpg|thumb|''Roses and Sunflowers'', 1886
Oil on canvas, 50 × 61 cm
[[Kunsthalle Mannheim]]]] {{clear}} == The Arles ''Sunflowers'' == In a letter to [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo]], dating from 21 or 22 August 1888, Vincent wrote: "I'm painting with the gusto of a Marseillais eating [[bouillabaisse]], which won’t surprise you when it's a question of painting large sunflowers." At this time he had three paintings on the go, and intended to do more; as he explained to his brother: "in the hope of living in a studio of our own with Gauguin, I'd like to do a decoration for the studio. Nothing but large sunflowers".[http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let666/letter.html Letter 666] To Theo van Gogh. Arles, Tuesday, 21 or Wednesday, 22 August 1888. Leaving aside the first two versions, all Arlesian ''Sunflowers'' are painted on [[French standard sizes for oil paintings|size 30 canvases]]. === The initial versions, August 1888 === None meets the descriptions supplied by van Gogh himself in his announcement of the series in every detail. The first version differs in size, is painted on a size 20 canvas—not on a size 15 canvas as indicatedDorn 1990, pp. 336–337—and all the others differ in the number of flowers depicted from van Gogh's announcement. The second was evidently enlarged and the initial composition altered by insertion of the two flowers lying in the foreground, center and right.Dorn 1990, pp. 344–348 Neither the third nor the fourth shows the dozen or 14 flowers indicated by the artist, but more—fifteen or sixteen.Dorn 1990, pp. 337–340; 340–343 and Van Tilborgh & Hendricks, pp. These alterations are executed ''wet-in-wet'' and therefore considered genuine rework—even the more so as they are copied to the ''repetitions'' of January 1889; there is no longer a trace of later alterations, at least in this aspect. File:Vincent Van Gogh - Three Sunflowers F453.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F453), first version: turquoise background
Oil on canvas, 73.5 × 60 cm
Private collection File:Six Sunflowers 1888.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F459), second version: royal-blue background
Oil on canvas, 98 × 69 cm
Formerly private collection, Japan, destroyed by fire in World War II on 6 August 1945{{cite web|url=http://www.vggallery.com/painting/p_0459.htm|title=Vincent van Gogh: The Paintings (Still Life: Vase with Five Sunflowers)|publisher=}} File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 128.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F456), third version: blue green background
Oil on canvas, 91 × 72 cm
[[Neue Pinakothek]], Munich, Germany File:Vincent Willem van Gogh 127.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F454), fourth version: yellow background

[[National Gallery]], London, England === The ''Repetitions'', January 1889 === File:Van Gogh Twelve Sunflowers.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F455), repetition of the 3rd version
Oil on canvas, 92 × 72.5 cm
[[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], Philadelphia, United States. File:Vincent van Gogh - Sunflowers - VGM F458.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F458), repetition of the 4th version (yellow background)
Oil on canvas, 95 × 73 cm
[[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam, Netherlands. File:Van Gogh Vase with Fifteen Sunflowers.jpg|''Sunflowers'' (F457), replica of the 4th version (yellow green background)
Oil on canvas, 100 × 76 cm
[[Sompo Japan Building|Sompo Japan Museum of Art]], Tokyo, Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.sompo-japan.co.jp/museum/english/|title=Seiji Togo Memorial Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Museum of Art|publisher=}} Both ''repetitions'' of the 4th version are no longer in their original state. In the Amsterdam version a strip of wood was added at the top—probably by van Gogh himself. The Tokyo version, however, was enlarged on all sides with strips of canvas, which were added at a later time—presumably by the first owner, [[Émile Schuffenecker]].See Dorn 1999, pp. The series is perhaps van Gogh's best known and most widely reproduced. In the 2000s debate arose regarding the authenticity of one of the paintings, and it has been suggested that this version may have been the work of [[Émile Schuffenecker]] or of [[Paul Gauguin]].Johnston, Bruce."[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1357627/Van-Goghs-25m-Sunflowers-is-a-copy-by-Gauguin.html Van Gogh's £25m Sunflowers is 'a copy by Gauguin']". ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 26 September 2001. Retrieved on 3 October 2009. Most experts, however, conclude that the work is genuine."[http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?lang=en&page=7985 Research confirms authenticity of Yasuda Sunflowers]". Van Gogh Museum, 7 February 2002. Retrieved on 19 October 2012."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1896422.stm Van Gogh 'fake' declared genuine]". BBC, 27 March 2002. Retrieved on 3 October 2009 === The ''Berceuse''-Triptych === {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = For complete data see previous illustrations | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Vincent Willem van Gogh 127.jpg | width1 = 175 | caption1 = ''Sunflowers'' (London version) | image2 = La Berceuse Augustine Roulin Otterlo.jpg | width2 = 175 | caption2 = ''Berceuse'' (Otterlo version) | image3 = Vincent Willem van Gogh 128.jpg | width3 = 175 | caption3 = ''Sunflowers'' (Munich version) }} [[File:Vincent van Gogh - Sunflowers Berceuse triptych - letter.jpg|thumb|Sketch of the triptych in a letter to Theo]] In January 1889, when Vincent had just finished the first repetitions of the ''Berceuse'' and the ''Sunflowers'' pendants, he told Theo: "I picture to myself these same canvases between those of the sunflowers, which would thus form torches or candelabra beside them, the same size, and so the whole would be composed of seven or nine canvases."{{cite web|url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/19/574.htm|title=Letter 574 – Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh : 28 January 1889|publisher=}} A definite hint for the arrangement of the triptych is supplied by Van Gogh's sketch in a letter of July 1889.{{cite web|url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/592.htm|title=Letter 592 – Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh : 22 May 1889|publisher=}} Later that year, Vincent selected both versions for his display at Les XX, 1890. == Sunflowers, friendship and gratitude == [[File:Paul Gauguin - Vincent van Gogh painting sunflowers - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Paul Gauguin: ''[[The Painter of Sunflowers]]'', 1888]] Van Gogh began painting in late summer 1888 and continued into the following year. One went to decorate his friend [[Paul Gauguin]]'s bedroom. The paintings show sunflowers in all stages of life, from full bloom to withering. The paintings were considered innovative for their use of the yellow spectrum, partly because newly invented [[pigment]]s made new colours possible. In a letter to Theo,Letter [http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/19/573.htm 573] Vincent wrote:
"It's a type of painting that changes its aspect a little, which grows in richness the more you look at it. Besides, you know that Gauguin likes them extraordinarily. He said to me about them, among other things: ‘that — ... that's... the flower’. You know that [[Georges Jeannin|Jeannin]] has the peony, [[Ernest Quost|Quost]] has the hollyhock, but I have the sunflower, in a way."[http://vangoghletters.org/vg/letters/let741/letter.html Letter 741] To Theo van Gogh. Arles, Tuesday, 22 January 1889.
== Subsequent history == [[File:Isaac Israels - Woman before %27%27Sunflowers%27%27 by van Gogh%2C 1917.JPG|thumb|upright|[[Isaac Israëls]]: ''Woman in front of Van Gogh's Sunflowers'', 1917. A close friend of Vincent Willem van Gogh, the artist's nephew, Israëls had a version of the ''Sunflowers'' on loan for a while.]] [[File:Schiele - Welke Sonnenblume.jpg|thumb|upright|''Dried Sunflowers'' by [[Egon Schiele]].]] On March 30, 1987, Japanese insurance magnate Yasuo Goto paid the equivalent of US $39,921,750 for van Gogh's ''Still Life: Vase with Fifteen Sunflowers'' at auction at [[Christie's]] London, at the time a [[List of most expensive paintings|record-setting amount for a work of art]].{{cite web |last=Clines |first=Francis X. |title= Van Gogh Sets Auction Record: $39.9 million |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=1987-03-31 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE3DB1F3DF932A05750C0A961948260 |accessdate=2008-06-13}} The price was over four times the previous record of about $12{{nbsp}}million paid for [[Andrea Mantegna]]'s ''[[Adoration of the Magi (Mantegna)|Adoration of the Magi]]'' in 1985. The record was broken a few months later with the purchase of another Van Gogh, ''[[Irises (painting)|Irises]]'', by [[Alan Bond (businessman)|Alan Bond]] for $53.9{{nbsp}}million at [[Sotheby's]], New York on November 11, 1987. While it is uncertain whether Yasuo Goto bought the painting himself or on behalf of his company, the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Japan, the painting currently resides at Seiji Togo Yasuda Memorial Museum of Modern Art in Tokyo. After the purchase, a controversy arose whether this is a genuine van Gogh or an [[Émile Schuffenecker]] forgery. === Provenances === Two Paris versions van Gogh exchanged with Gauguin in December 1887 or January 1888, were both sold to [[Ambroise Vollard]]: one in January 1895 and the other in April 1896. The first canvas resided for a short time with Félix Roux, but was reacquired by [[Vollard]] and sold to [[Degas]], then from his estate to Rosenberg, then to Hahnloser and bequested to the [[Kunstmuseum Bern]]. The second was acquired by the Dutch collector Hoogendijk at the sale of his collection by Kann, who ceded the painting to Richard Bühler and then via Thannhauser to the Metropolitan Museum in New York. Two of van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' paintings never left the artist's estate: the study for one of the Paris versions (F377) and the repetition of fourth version (F458). Both are in the possession of the Vincent van Gogh Foundation, established 1962 by Vincent Willem van Gogh, the artist's nephew, and on permanent loan to the [[Van Gogh Museum]], Amsterdam. Five other versions are recorded in the Van Gogh estate papers:Dorn 1999 and Stolwijk & Veenenbos 2002 *the final Paris version (F.452) in the artist's estate was sold 1909 via C. M. van Gogh, [[The Hague]] (J. H. de Bois) to Kröller-Müller *(F457) sold 1894 to [[Émile Schuffenecker]]. (Tokyo version). *(F456) sold 1905 via [[Paul Cassirer]] to [[Hugo von Tschudi]]. (Munich version). *(F459) sold 1908 C. M. van Gogh (J. H. de Bois), The Hague to Fritz Meyer-Fierz, Zürich (destroyed Japan 1945). *(F454) sold 1924 via Ernest Brown & Phillips (The [[Leicester Galleries]]) to the [[Tate Gallery]]; since on permanent loan to the [[National Gallery]], London. (London version). Two Arles versions left the artist's estate unrecorded: *(F453) (private collection). Sold 1891 to Octave Mirbeau, Paris, (via Tanguy, Paris) for £12 (about £1,300 in 2013 £). Sold 1996 to a private collector for an undisclosed sum.Bailey, 2013, p. 202 *(F455) (Philadelphia version). == Notes == {{Reflist|30em}} === References === *Bailey, Martin: ''The Sunflowers Are Mine: The Story of Van Gogh's Masterpiece'', Frances Lincoln Limited (2013), {{ISBN|978-0-7112-3298-3}} *Dorn, Roland: ''"Décoration": Vincent van Goghs Werkreihe für das Gelbe Haus in Arles'', Georg Olms Verlag, Hildesheim, Zürich & New York, 1990, pp. 58–61, 73–80, 113–117, 335–348, 455–462 {{ISBN|3-487-09098-8}} *Hoffmann, Konrad: ''Zu van Goghs Sonnenblumenbildern'', Zeitschrift für Kunstgeschichte 31, 1968, pp. 27–58 * {{cite book|title=Van Gogh Repetitions|date=2013|publisher=The Phillips Collection|isbn=978-0-300-19082-3|editor=Eliza Rathbone|display-editors=etal}} *Stolwijk, Chris, & Veenenbos, Han: ''The account book of Theo van Gogh and Jo van Gogh-Bonger'', Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam & Primavera Press, Leiden 2002 {{ISBN|90-74310-82-6}} *Tellegen, Annet: ''Vincent en Gauguin: schilderijenruil in Paris'', Museumjournaal 11, 1966, pp. 42–45 *Van Tilborgh, Louis & Hendriks, Ella: ''The Tokyo 'Sunflowers': a genuine repetition by Van Gogh or a Schuffenecker forgery?'', Van Gogh Museum Journal 2001, pp. 17–43 *[[Bogomila Welsh-Ovcharov|Welsh-Ovcharov, Bogomila]]: ''The Ownership of Vincent van Gogh's 'Sunflowers''', ''[[The Burlington Magazine]]'', March 1998, page.title: The Camera Club of New York

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Nyc-camera-club.jpg|thumb|West 37th Street]] Since 1884, '''The Camera Club of New York''' has been a forum to explore [[photography]]. Though the Club was created by well-to-do 'gentlemen' photography enthusiasts seeking a refuge from the mass popularization of the medium in the 1880s, it accepted its first woman as a member, Miss Elizabeth A. Slade, in 1887, only four years after its inception, and later came to accept new ideas and new approaches to the medium.
Over the years the Club helped launch revolutionary new approaches to photography and nurture many photographers who later became giants in the field. [[Alfred Stieglitz]] used the Club as a forum and venue to convince a still skeptical public that photography was an art worthy of comparison to painting. Later, as the medium matured, the Club was again the place where the new "[[straight photography]]" approach would emerge. [[Paul Strand]], who joined the Camera Club at 17, was introduced to a camera at the Club that had a right-angle viewfinder, allowing one to photograph people unaware. Strand used this camera to produce some of his most memorable images on the streets of New York, including Blind Woman and Wall Street.
[[File:Take our picture please 0085.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Entrance]] The Camera Club was also an important place to hear about new advances in photography. For instance, X-Ray photography was demonstrated there in 1898 and the [[Autochrome Lumière]] process, an early form of color photography, in 1909. In 1930 [[Willard D Morgan]] first introduced the new [[Leica Camera|Leica]] camera to Club members. Among the important lectures held at the Club were Aero Photography by [[Edward Steichen]] in 1921 and The Life and Work of [[Eugène Atget]] by [[Berenice Abbott]] in 1931. Later, [[Richard Avedon]] lectured on fashion Photography in 1949.
Today, the Camera Club continues to function as an important resource for photography. The club offers classes in basic camera and darkroom skills, which help nurture and create new pioneers of photography and workspaces for established and emerging photographers. Lectures and exhibits are an important part of the club's program. Since 1999 such important photographers as [[Eugene Richards]], [[Nigel Parry]], [[Duane Michals]], [[Oliver Weber]], [[Andres Serrano]], [[Eddie Adams (photographer)|Eddie Adams]], and [[Henry Horenstein]] have exhibited and lectured at the club.<ref>[http://www.cameraclubny.org/lecture_series_past.html Past lecture series speakers.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828042926/http://www.cameraclubny.org/lecture_series_past.html |date=2008-08-28 }} Camera Club of New York, 2008. Retrieved August 7, 2008.</ref>
The Camera Club of New York is located at 126 Baxter Street, New York, NY 10013.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|The Camera Club of New York}} * {{Official website|http://www.baxterst.org/}} * Wingfield, Valerie. [https://web.archive.org/web/20061015115303/http://www.nypl.org/research/chss/spe/rbk/faids/cameraclub.pdf Camera Club of New York records, 1889-1983''.] New York Public Library, July 1993.
{{coord|40|45|17|N|73|59|38.4|W|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Camera Club of New York, the}} [[Category:American photography organizations]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in New York City]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Photography organizations established in the 19th century]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1884]] [[Category:1884 establishments in New York (state)]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Bosch laatste oordeel drieluik.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 450px | title = The Last Judgment | artist = [[Hieronymus Bosch]] and workshop | year = c. 1486 | type = [[Oil painting|Oil-on-wood]] [[triptych]] | height_metric = 99 | width_metric = 117.5 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = | museum = [[Groeningemuseum]], [[Bruges]] }} '''''The Last Judgment''''' is a [[triptych]] of disputed authorship, either by [[Hieronymus Bosch]], his workshop, or a collaboration between artist and workshop. It was created after 1486. The triptych currently resides at the [[Groeningemuseum]] in [[Bruges]], [[Belgium]]. The outside of the shutters are painted in [[grisaille]], while the inside shutters and center are oil on panel. ==History== The work belonged to E. Gravet's collection, and then to that of Seligman, in [[Paris]]. In 1907 it was acquired by A. Bernaert, who donated it to the city of Bruges. In 1936 it was cleaned and was restored again in 1959. In that occasion, the [[grisaille]] painting of the external shutters were discovered, although damaged. The painting above the internal frames is lost. The attribution of the work is dubious, due to its mediocre quality. [[Dendrochronology|Dendrochronologic]] analysis dated it from not before 1486.{{cite book |first=Franca |last=Varallo |title=Bosch |publisher=Skira |location=Milan |year=2004 |isbn=978-88-572-0615-8}} ==Description== The painting's composition has similarities to [[The Last Judgment (Bosch triptych)|''The Last Judgment'' triptych]] in Vienna and the ''[[Garden of Earthly Delights]]'': both show the Garden of Eden in the left panel and the Hell at right. Like in other contemporary [[Flemish art|Flemish]] triptychs, the shutters are externally painted in [[grisaille]] with an ''Coronation with Thorns''. In the central panel is Christ as a judge within a celestial sphere, flanked by angels who are playing the Trumpets of Last Judgement, and by the apostles. Below him is the punishment of sinners which, like the ''Last Judgement'' of Vienna, continues in the Hell depiction at right. At left is the Paradise, where the blessed souls are being shipped to Eden on a boat with a pink tent. The tower is a symbol of the Fountain of Eternal Youth, a more articulate version of which appears in the ''Garden of Delights''. The central panel is mostly occupied by insect-like demons who torture the men, punishments including burning, eating impure food (the gluttonous) etc., all inspired by [[Netherlandish Proverbs]]. The infernal city at right is under siege by demons, while a fire is visible in the far background. ==See also== *''[[The Haywain Triptych]]'' *[[The Last Judgment (Bosch triptych fragment)|''The Last Judgment'' (Bosch triptych fragment)]] *[[The Last Judgment (Bosch triptych)|''The Last Judgment'' (Bosch triptych)]] *[[Early Netherlandish art]] *[[Triptych]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book |first=Eileen |last=Romano |title=Bosco |publisher=Unidad Editorial |year=2005 |isbn=84-89780-69-2}} *{{cite book |first=Franca |last=Varallo |title=Bosch |publisher=Skira |location=Milan |year=2004 |isbn=978-88-572-0615-8}}
{{Hieronymus Bosch}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Last Judgment}} [[Category:Paintings by Hieronymus Bosch]] [[Category:Triptychs]] [[Category:1480s paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Groeningemuseum]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Jesus]] [[Category:Angels in art]]

revision.comment: /* Notable fellowship award recipients */Added name of additional recipient of fellowship
revision.text:
'''The Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation''' was founded in 1918 by [[Louis Comfort Tiffany]] to operate his estate, [[Laurelton Hall]], in [[Cold Spring Harbor, New York|Cold Spring Harbor]], [[Long Island]]. It was designed to be a summer retreat for artists and craftspeople. In 1946 the estate closed and the foundation changed its purpose from a retreat to the bestowing of grants to artists.
In closing down her father's residence after his death, [[George Frederick Kunz]]' daughter, Ruby Zinsser, donated two paintings by [[Louis C. Tiffany]] to the Tiffany Foundation. "In 1935, the family of George F. Kunz donated two Tiffany paintings to the picture gallery." In this, she was following her father's inclination, since he had previously donated a Syrian bracelet and mineral collection to the Foundation in 1928.<ref>Frelinghuysen, Alice Cooney. Louis Comfort Tiffany and Laurelton Hall: An Artist’s Country Estate. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. 2006. Pages 210, 213.</ref>
== Notable fellowship award recipients == * [[Guy Anderson]], an American painter from the [[Northwest School (art)|Northwest School]] * [[Nicole Cherubini]], an American visual artist and ceramicist * [[Moyra Davey]], a New York-based artist specializing in photography, video and writing * [[Janet Doub Erickson]], American craftswoman, blockprinter, and author * John Drury (1997) NYC * [[Teresita Fernández]], New York City based artist * [[Ann Gardner]], an American glass artist, mosaicist, and installation artist * [[Adam Helms]], an American artist based in Brooklyn, New York * [[Evan Holloway]], an artist based in Los Angeles. *[[Luise Clayborn Kaish]], an American artist known for her work in sculpture, painting, and collage * [[Karen LaMonte]], artist. * [[Ciel Bergman]], then known as Cheryl Bowers, an American painter. * [[Dante Marioni]], an American glass artist, work featured in the National Museum of Art, [[Renwick Gallery]] * [[Josiah McElheny]], artist/sculptor, award winner of the Foundation's 1995 Biennial Competition * [[Paul Meltsner]], WPA era painter and muralist * [[George Joseph Mess]], a 1931 award recipient, was an American painter, [[printmaking|printmaker]], [[commercial art|commercial artist]], and art educator based in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]<ref>{{cite web| author=| title =Person Record: George Mess | work = | publisher =Minnetrista | date = | url =https://minnetrista.pastperfectonline.com/byperson?keyword=Mess%2C+George| format = | accessdate =September 10, 2018}}</ref> * Veraldo J. Cariani, Brown County, Indiana and Massachusetts Painter, 1920. * [[Wardell Milan]], New York based artist * [[Eric Norstad]], Northern California ceramicist and architect * [[Rinaldo Paluzzi]], American/Spanish painter and sculptor * [[Francis Quirk|Francis J. Quirk]] American Painter 1932 * [[Andrew Raftery]], American engraver and painter. Recipient of Louis Comfort Tiffany Award in 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/andrew-stein-raftery/|title = Andrew Stein Raftery|date = |accessdate = 5 April 2015|website = John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> * [[Edna Reindel]], American painter, illustrator, sculptor, and muralist. Recipient of Fellowship in 1926 & 1932 * [[Noel Rockmore]], an American painter from NYC and New Orleans. Recipient of Fellowship in 1956 & 1963 * [[Larry Sultan]], an American photographer * [[Marc Trujillo]], North American artist/painter * [[Anne Wilson (artist)|Anne Wilson]], a Chicago-based, interdisciplinary artist * [[Marilyn Minter]], painter and photographer
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *{{Official website|louiscomforttiffanyfoundation.org}} * [http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/88550/rec/13 Louis Comfort Tiffany and Laurelton Hall: an artist's country estate], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on the Foundation
{{DEFAULTSORT:Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, The}} [[Category:Arts organizations based in New York (state)]] [[Category:Arts foundations based in the United States]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1918]] [[Category:1918 establishments in New York (state)]]

page.title: The Tale of the Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Google mapz|Google mapz]] ([[User talk:Google mapz|talk]]) to last version by ClueBot NG
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox Folk tale |Folk_Tale_Name = The Tale of the Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son |Image_Name = |Image_Caption = |AKA = The Shifty Lad |Aarne-Thompson Grouping = |Mythology = |Country = [[Scotland]] |Region = |Origin_Date = |Published_In = ''[[Popular Tales of the West Highlands]]''
''[[The Lilac Fairy Book]]'' |Related = ''[[The Master Thief]]'' }} '''The Tale of the Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son''' is a Scottish [[fairy tale]] collected by [[John Francis Campbell]] in ''[[Popular Tales of the West Highlands]]''. [[Andrew Lang]] included it, as '''The Shifty Lad''' in ''[[The Lilac Fairy Book]]''. ==Synopsis== {{plot|date=January 2013}} A widow wanted her son to learn a trade. He insisted that he wanted to be a thief. She predicted he would end up hanging from a bridge. One day he did not go to church, and told her that the first trade she heard when she came out would be his. He came to the path and shouted "Thievery" in a disguised voice. She again predicted he would hang from the bridge but gave him to the Black Gallows Bird to learn the trade. The man taught him, and then said they must rob a man who had sold his cattle. On Halloween, they hid in the loft. The shifty lad went down and stirred up the cattle, sending people out; while they were gone, he stole nuts and sewed a leather hide to the thief. He cracked nuts, though the thief warned him he would be heard. He was heard, and the people came, and the thief ran off with the hide still attached. The people said he was stealing the hide and chased him. The Shifty Lad stole the gold and silver while they were gone, and brought them to the thief; they split them. Soon, a tenant sent a man to get a wether to give as a wedding gift. The Shifty Lad bet his master that he could steal it from the man's back. When he was coming, the lad put a dirty shoe in his path; the man said that if he had the other one, he would clean this one and have a pair. The Shifty Lad ran ahead of his, and put the shoe in the way again. The man went back to get the other, and the lad took the wether and the shoes and won his bet. The tenant sent the same man after a kid. The lad bleated like the wether, and when the man searched for it, thinking to come back with both, the lad stole the kid. The third time, the tenant directed him to never let the wether go, and so he brought it home. The shifty lad had his master hang him, and let him down when he kicked his legs. He praised it, and his master let him hang him, but the lad killed him. His wife was angry, and the lad fled. He took service with a wright who lived next to the king's storehouse, and broke into it to steal. The gifts persuaded the wright and his wife to let him. At the advice of the Seanagal, the king set a hogshead of pitch to catch the thief, and it caught the wright. The lad cut off his head to prevent their learning who he was. The king displayed the body to discover who grieved at the sight, but when the wright's wife cried out, he cut his foot and pretended she cried over that. Then the body was hung from a tree for the same reason. The lad took a horse with casks of whiskey by them, as if he were hiding from the soldiers. They chased him, and he fled, leaving the horse. They took it back, found the whiskey, and became drunk. The lad took the body. The king sent a black pig about to dig up the body. When it rooted about the wright's house, the lad sent the soldiers inside to eat and drink while it searched. He killed the pig and buried it while they ate. The king sent men to discover where people had pig's flesh they could not account for; the lad killed the soldiers sent to his house, and then started a rumor that the soldiers meant to massacre them, so all the people killed the soldiers. The Seanagal advised to give a ball, since the man would be the boldest and dance with the princess; when the lad did so, the Seanagal marked him with a black dot, but the lad saw it and marked the Seanagal himself with two and twenty other men with one. The king decided that he was beaten, and that he wanted so clever a man for his son-in-law. He had all the men with the black dots put in a room, and had a child give one an apple. The lad drew him with a shaving and a drone, and the child gave him the apple. They took the shaving and drone, but the child remembered them and still gave him the apple, so the shifty lad married the princess. One day, while they walked on the bridge, the lad told the princess that his mother said he would hang from that bridge. She said that if he wished to go over the wall, she would hold him by her handkerchief. He did, and hanged there, but a cry went up about a fire, startling the princess. She let go. The lad fell and died. ==See also== *[[The Master Thief]] {{Portal bar |Children's literature}} ==External links== *[http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/pt1/pt126.htm ''The Tale of the Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Tale of the Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son}} [[Category:Scottish fairy tales|Shifty Lad, the Widow's Son]] [[Category:Fairy tales]]

[[File:Pakistani_truck.jpg|thumb|right|Most Pakistani trucks have an augmented rooftop to increase space for decoration.]] [[File:A decorated truck in India.jpg|thumb|upright|A decorated truck in India, showing black ''[[jutti]]'' and ''[[Nazar Battu|nazar battu]]'']] [[File:Sisters_getting_ready.jpg|thumb|The backs of Pakistani trucks are often intricately decorated.]] '''Truck art''' is a popular form of regional decoration in [[South Asia]], with [[Pakistan]]i and [[India]]n trucks featuring elaborate floral patterns and calligraphy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pakistaniat.com/2008/06/18/pakistans-indigenous-truck-art/ |title=Pakistan’s Indigenous Art of Truck Painting |last1=Mughal |first1=Owais |last2= |first2= |date=June 18, 2008 |website=All Things Pakistan |publisher= |access-date=February 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativeyatra.com/culture/tracing-truck-art-beyond-horn-ok-please-india-and-pakistans-truck-art-tradition/|title=Tracing Truck Art beyond 'Horn OK Please': India and Pakistan’s Truck Art tradition|date=16 November 2016|publisher=Creative Yatra|language=English|accessdate=31 July 2017|quote=Largely a domestic art in its early years especially in North India and Pakistan, the ideation of beautifying trucks, lorries, and rickshaws with multifaceted patterns and calligraphy was common.}}</ref><ref name="McKenzie2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/travel/article/india-truck-art-travel-design/index.html|title=Pimp my ride: The psychedelic world of Indian truck art|last=McKenzie|first=Sheena|date=5 August 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|language=English|accessdate=31 July 2017|quote=For truckers in India, that means a kaleidoscope of colors, slogans, and intricately painted symbols that are as much about bling -- as shrewd business sense. ..."A better looking truck attracts more business," says Shantanu Suman, graphic designer and filmmaker behind 2013 documentary "Horn Please," which explores India's spectacular truck art tradition.}}</ref>
Pakistani decorated trucks servicing Afghanistan came to be known as '''jingle trucks''' by American troops and contractors.
=="Jingle truck" origin== The term jingle truck comes from United States [[military slang]], coined by servicemen in [[Afghanistan]], although it may date to the British colonial period. The term came to be because of the "jingle" sound that the trucks make due to the chains hanging from the bumpers of the vehicles.<ref name=definition>{{cite web |url=http://www.doubletongued.org/index.php/citations/jingle_truck_1/ |title=A Way With Words |last=Barrett |first=Grant |access-date=2 September 2017}}</ref>
==Practice== Many [[truck]]s and [[bus]]es are highly customized and decorated by their owners. External truck decoration can cost thousands of dollars.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.amherst.edu/magazine/issues/05spring/trucks/index.html |title=On Wings of Diesel: The Decorated Trucks of Pakistan |last1=Elias |first1=Jamal |last2= |first2= |date=2005 |website=Amherst Magazine |publisher= |access-date=February 10, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517232757/http://www3.amherst.edu/magazine/issues/05spring/trucks/index.html |archivedate=May 17, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The decoration often contains elements that remind the truck drivers of home, since they may be away from home for months at a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-19292392 |title=Pakistan's truck art inspires catwalk fashion range - BBC News |website=Bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-23}}</ref> Decoration may include structural changes, [[paintings]], [[calligraphy]], and ornamental decor like mirror work on the front and back of vehicles and wooden carvings on the truck doors. Depictions of various historical scenes and poetic verses are also common.<ref name="saudiaramcoworld.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200502/masterpieces.to.go.the.trucks.of.pakistan.htm |title=Masterpieces to Go: The Trucks of Pakistan |last1=Covington |first1=Richard |last2= |first2= |date=Spring 2005 |website=Saudi Aramco World |publisher= |access-date=February 10, 2015}}</ref> Outfitting is often completed at a coach workshop.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.upenn.edu/pennnews/current/research/101906.html |title=The Painted Trucks of Pakistan |last1=Nyland |first1=Tim |last2= |first2= |date=October 19, 2006 |website=Penn Current |publisher=University of Pennsylvania |access-date=February 10, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110113101127/http://www.upenn.edu/pennnews/current/research/101906.html |archivedate=January 13, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Chains and pendants often dangle off the front bumper.<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/truck-art-tradition-in-pakistan/28548217.html Pakistan's Dazzling 'Jingle Trucks'] [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (www.rferl.org). June 14, 2017. Retrieved on 2017-06-19.</ref>
===Artists=== One of the most prominent truck artists is [[Haider Ali (artist)|Haider Ali]]. Trained by his father from his youth, he first came to international attention in 2002 when he painted an authentic Pakistani truck as part of the [[Smithsonian Folklife Festival]].<ref name=fastco>{{cite news |last=Hart |first=Hugh |date=14 November 2014 |title= A Jingle Truck Artist Brings The Mobile Art Of Pakistan To America |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3037627/a-jingle-truck-artist-brings-the-mobile-art-of-pakistan-to-america |work=Fast Company |location= |access-date=17 August 2017 }}</ref>
===Regional styles=== [[File:A road leads to Sharda, Neelum Valley AJK.JPG|thumb|Many local buses in Pakistan are decorated with truck art.]] In Pakistan, [[Karachi]] is a major city center for truck art, though there are other hubs in [[Rawalpindi]], [[Swat, Pakistan|Swat]], [[Peshawar]], [[Quetta]] and [[Lahore]]. Trucks from [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]] and Peshawar are often heavily trimmed with wood, while trucks from Rawalpindi and [[Islamabad]] often feature plastic work. Camel bone ornamentation and predominance of red colours is commonly seen on trucks decorated in [[Sindh]].<ref name="saudiaramcoworld.com"/>
In India, the [[Delhi]]-based artist Tilak Raj Dhir states that the slogans he adds to his truck art, which is prevalent throughout the [[National Capital Region (India)|National Capital Region]], often change with the socio-political atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/meet-the-men-who-convert-trucks-into-colourful-canvases/story-mmF7FbEhGr2FUfpIwqTi1M.html|title=Meet the men who convert trucks into colourful canvases|last=Sharma|first=Manoj|date=20 April 2015|publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]|language=English|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> Truck art in Urdu is sometime called Phool Patti.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1403009/heritage-saying-it-with-flowers|title=HERITAGE: SAYING IT WITH FLOWERS|publisher=dawn.com|language=English}}</ref>
==Influence== [[File:Naan_sense_peshawar.jpg|thumb|Truck art decorates the façade of a business in [[Peshawar]], [[Pakistan]].]] Truck art has extended beyond the decoration and ornamentation of trucks into other forms and media.
=== Cars === Though cars are not traditionally decorated in South Asia, there are examples of cars embellished in a truck art style. In 2009, The Foxy Shahzadi, a 1974 VW Beetle decordated in a truck art style, traveled from Pakistan to France over a 25-day journey.<ref name=dawn>{{cite news|title=Foxy Shahzadi running away for good |url=http://www.dawn.com/news/880216/foxy-shahzadi-running-away-for-good|accessdate=13 June 2014|newspaper=The Dawn|date=24 December 2010}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|last=Walsh|first=Declan|title=From Pakistan to Paris, by VW Beetle |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/09/pakistan-paris-vw-beetle|accessdate=13 June 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=9 November 2010}}</ref> In the Indian city of [[Mumbai]], some drivers decorate their taxis in a truck art style.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/indian-truck-art-and-taxi-fabric-project-322688|title=Indian Truck Art and Taxi Design-artnet News|last=Kinsella|first=Eileen|date=5 August 2015|publisher=[[Artnet]]|language=English|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
===Fashion=== The lively colors of Pakistani trucks have inspired multiple fashion designers.<ref name=bbc.fashion>{{cite news|title=Pakistan's truck art inspires catwalk fashion range |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-19292392|accessdate=13 June 2015|newspaper=BBC|date=17 August 2012}}</ref> The Italian fashion company [[Dolce & Gabbana]] used truck art-inspired displays in a 2015 campaign.<ref name=tribune>{{cite news|last=Sheikh|first=Ibriz|title=Pakistani truck art takes over streets of Milan |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/894788/pakistani-truck-art-takes-over-streets-of-milan/|accessdate=13 September 2015|newspaper=The Express Tribune|date=30 May 2015}}</ref> Although used more often on women's fashion, some men's clothing have been inspired by South Asian truck art.<ref name=fashion>{{cite web|url=http://pakistantruckart.com/2010/03/06/truck-art-and-fashion/|title=Truck art and fashion |publisher=pakistantruckart.com|accessdate=16 October 2015}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:The symbol of art (1015808925).jpg|Decorations can be highly detailed. File:Pakistani_decorated_Wheels_Trucks.jpg|All parts of the truck are highly embellished. File:Such beauty (1015799377).jpg|Wood-paneling is often carved in high detail. File:Sanjaram - truck in India.jpg|Intricately designed truck cab. File:Gilgit-Skardu_road.JPG|Decorated trucks can be found in even the most remote corners of Pakistan. File:Pakistani_Truck_Art.jpg|Truck beds are also sometimes decorated. File:The_details_of_art_(1015803457).jpg|Up close view of artwork. File:A truck being painted near Cochin, India.jpg|Truck being painted in [[Kochi]].
